comment: Once you let them dictate rules against fairness, they will continue the problem. It only gets worse. Rights will be trampled and compromised.

Why can't the higher ups in journalism circles in Spain help these women? How about the former head of the Spanish Press Federation, Arsenio Escolar?  Couldn't he help stage an intervention? What year is it again?  It feels like Spain is still in the dark ages.  These men have the power, and they should not ignore the valid complaints of these women who should be treated as equals.

Hopefully the country of Spain can provide women generalists opportunities after they complete schooling. Currently it looks like their prospects are not so bright. Pedro SÃ¡nchez, president of Spain is probably already working on this. They can Institute new legislation in order to balance the field for women.

I understand why you think having a rule that you believe is unfair would be troubling and lead to more unfairness. I think we  need to look at the bigger picture here. A rule that you see is unfair might seem very fair to another person. Fairness is a very subjective issue and all of us will see it differently based on our experiences. Can you think of a rule or law that has been widely praised that you might see as unfair to yourself or others? Sometimes we need to look outside our own biases and see that other people can see things quite differently. Once we can see those differences we can then come together and find solutions that can meet all of our needs. I suggest that all of us meet with others with different opinions and listen to their views. That will be a great step for us all.

I am much more likely to trust the people in charge of these organizations than the women striking. How do we know what they say is true? If there were real issues, the people in charge would handle it. Feminist protests like this usually blow things out of proportion, let's be honest!

Wouldn't protesting to their bosses or on air do more than what the government is doing? The protesting is important, it's just they seem to be yelling at the clouds. What can protesting in the street do to help what's going on in their job's building? Even a famous social scientist Dr. John Doe suggested that targeted dialogue to those directed involved with an issue will be more impactful than public demonstrations in certain cases. I would think the emphasis would remain on dialogue and progress and not public displays that won't really bring the change.

Journalists have done important work for all countries for as long as they've been a thing! They have always been some of the most important people in democracies and Spain hasn't treated theirs right. Seeing them take their fate into their own hands is great! Spain needs to get back to seeing how important they are.

Oh come on now, there are plenty of complaints by these women journalists that could easily be verified. Plus these are the very same complaints that is heard in other areas of the world, there is zero chance that these women protesters are standing up under false pretenses. Many of their concerns have been well-documented, showing the imbalance and unfair conditions they face. Maybe now it's high time that relevant authorities start listening to these brave women and take a stand to change the situation, instead of turning a deaf ear to their valid concerns.

Whoa there, let's not get crazy! Demanding equal treatment isn't going to cause an uprising there the rules and everything else get changed. Women are just fed up with not being treated fairly, surely you can understand how that effects women everywhere? Let's not lose sight of things that are even bigger issues like climate change, world hunger, or economic crises. It's about priorities.

I think these brave female journalists in Spain can do plenty by protesting in the streets, it's important to get the word out about injustices to the common folk. I also am skeptical about your expert, I have never heard of this 'famous' Dr. John Doe. It honestly sounds like a very generic and made up name and only serves to denigrate your argument. I would hope that next time you would impart some of the qualifications of this Doctor, it would greatly improve the believability of his inclusion. Either way, Spain needs to close this pay gap and up the representation of women in the media. I am hopeful that almost all experts and commoners could find agreement in this!

I think it's fine for women to demand equal pay and power, but then what? I can see the movement taking more and more, until women hold the power in society and men will go on strike for equal representation. The article suggests this movement is spreading to other areas other than media, so I think it's important to make sure equality is achieved slowly and sensibly and doesn't slide into a negative situation.

Good for these ladies!  They are professionals and should be treated as equals and with respect.  I admire them for their courage, and hope their protests will bring awareness to discrimination and harassment in the workplace. This takes courage and will expose power imbalances for female journalist worldwide.
This is the problem. The wrong people in charge. There must be more oversight into these programs.
NGOs often operate for self-enrichment. Most don't do much more than burn cash on admin cost. While those in need get little to nothing.

From an American perspective, this just sounds like a good idea. How much has Russia and China and so on interfered in our elections? I bet Slovakia and most other countries probably have the same experience. Probably a very standard thing globally. Everyone should be able to identify all foreign interference in their internal affairs.
The regulation of NGOs are necessary. Though it can lead to silencing. Some NGOs do good work needed by the society.

Yes.  Let's worry about election interference and not homelessness.  Lets be real here.  NGOs do serve an important purpose, like providing essential services to those in need.  Of all the problems that governments should worry about,  NGOs influencing elections is not in the top 10.     Not even in the top 100,  really.    Lets focus on skyrocketing healthcare costs instead.  Or how about out crumbling educational system?  I guess kids don't need to go to school,  though,  and it's fine if Grandma has to sell her house to pay for her medicine.

I can see Fico's point of view. Up until recently, all countries have had the tradition of really only allowing their own people to work and live in their country. Now more and more countries are going against that and importing tons of foreigners which will eventually lead to the erosion of even more traditions in the country, Traditions are important. We all have them for a reason!
It's natural for ousted leaders to call foul play. He does not think he was bad in office. It is easier to blame a conspiracy for his loss of power.

It is best to overlook the situation and then make a decision. It can be wiser to overlook all aspects of the situation and then decide how to proceed. No rushing of conclusions without knowing the full picture.

Tighter regulations will eventually just lead to all NGOs ceasing to exist there. They will regulate them so strictly that either they won't be able to afford it, or they will be intimidated into leaving. This will lead to the politicians getting away with whatever they want. This is happening due to an NGO investigating a murder, isn't it? The fact that they want to regulate ngos now means that they don't like that a murder is being investigated!

Something needs to be done, but I agree with the commenter who said that too much tightening of regulations in regards to NGOs may eventually lead to NGOs ceasing to exist. It is critical to find the right balance when it comes to tightening regulations. Also, more international measures may need to be configured in order to ensure the safe operation of NGOs.

This article is so obviously biased that I find it difficult to take it seriously. Its lionization of Soros seems wildly misplaced, but when it's followed immediately by the disclaimer that Soros is funding the organization which produced it, all confusion is dispersed like fog. I did learn some things about Slovak politics though. So the article was worth reading, if for that alone.

Fico sounds like Trump: the anti-immigration stance, the scapegoating of George Soros, the engagement with wild, unprovable conspiracy theories. NGOs play an important role in international affairs and often do a lot of work that governments themselves can't do. Perhaps more transparency in the government would do more good and build more public trust than targeting NGOs.

I've seen this reduction in press transparency in other countries, and it is concerning, but I don't want to assume anything. While it is true that some governments that restrict press access have corruption issues, I don't want to automatically assume that the PNG government is corrupt. Perhaps they have something to hide, but perhaps not. Hopefully, as time goes on, they will show that they are on the level.

To me this just seems to want to placate a blind belief that more press access equals good. I find it perfectly acceptable that Papua New Guinea doesn't want to blindly open the floodgates to journalists given their situation. Western countries know very little about Papua New Guinea and anything happening there. This results in journalists almost entirely framing the debate of what to think. Lots of journalists are simply going to exacerbate anything they find to drum up interest

It seems like the prime minister of Papua New Guinea no longer wants to discuss issues plaguing his country with the press. Couldn't this just hinder the public from knowing what's happening in the political arena? Why must they add all these new Hoops for journalists to go through in order to contact them? I'm all for government transparency. Unless your president is tweeting at 3:00 in the morning. But this seems to be an extreme example of the opposite.

Having to get permission to ask a world leader questions is not natural. It indicates something is very wrong. Its not in our nature to act this way when we want or need answers to important societal issues. What is natural is what we have in the west where lots of people regularly talk to our leaders and have transparency.

Why are we putting in more restrictions? Does this really provide a benefit or is it a way to distract from something else?  Are there any benefits I am unaware of? It seems to go against a need for freedom of expression, a natural want/need for all people. What problem is this actually solving? What do these restrictions improve? What do you think?

What's with the comment about Western countries knowing very little about PNG, like that's a good reason to stop journalists from going there? How are the Western audiences supposed to learn about the country without journalists going there and writing about them? We should encourage foreign journalists to go there to solve the problems you're talking about.

I think we all want to see freedom of press. It is important that the government remain transparent and press is an important part of making that happen. The press encourages honesty and transparency. I think we can all agree that the government should be open with the press. Can't we all agree openness with the press is important for the government?

So you bring up Western countries and their lack of knowledge of the country. They you say that lack of knowledge leads to them writing stories in which they entirely frame the debate. Don't you think that this whole issue of making it harder for the foreign journalist to come in, is going to make this a bigger issue? How are they supposed to learn about the country and its issues in order to write more balanced stories so they don't frame their from their own point of view? I think that the PM should be worried about more important things that the media. Or perhaps he is, and slicing the media or making it tougher for them to get access will ease those worries. Hence the corruption issues. Maybe if he was more transparent, the media would not be clamoring for access?

This may be unintuitive, but lots of people in the world aren't interested in the complete free flow of information. It just leads to endless polarization and divisions in society. The majority in PNG might be completely for this, and if they are, then we have no right to question them.

Any government that tries to make it harder for journalists to do their job is not to be trusted. There is no good reason for it. The people of new guinea need to stop this in its tracks. If they let the government make it harder for jounalists, they will eventually try to make it like China and then the people won't be informed about anything.

I appreciate your optimism, and I suppose the government hasn't done anything "wrong" yet, but it's also true that governments that are secure in their position do not limit press freedoms. The only reason to worry about the press is if one is concerned about what the press will write. But it's also historically true that these measures are not popular and are self-defeating for the governments, so I can see a brighter day ahead.

Corrupt, unpopular governments distracting from their problems by ignoring their issues and limiting public information is a story as old as time. It's almost tradition at this point. It's unfortunate that so many people will accept that things have just always been this way. Hopefully the activists and the press and the rest can come together and put a stop to these kinda actions.

Allowing crimes like this to go unchecked is just going to cause more crimes of this type. Not only that but if journalists are being targeted and harmed and murdered who is going to be brave enough to investigate crimes and tell the truth to the public. We must protect the truth tellers for them and for all.

It is good to see that an unsolved murder seems to be closer to being solved. I am concerned with all the jubilation over someone being charged in this case. Everyone seems to be acting as this person is guilty when it is just a charge. It is very frightening when we are immediately assumed to be guilty on just an accusation. What comes next after this? Will we just put people in jail for life upon being accused? After that seems to be accepted, will we just execute them before any trial? I understand people wanting justice but we must be careful when throwing out systems that protect the innocent. I hope we will all think about this and have discussion with others to make sure we don't lead ourselves down this dark path.

This is a great step in the right direction. Imagine how bad it could get if nothing ever came of these killings and these corrupt figures just found out they could get away with this kind of behavior. What eventually comes is practically a mafia state. Corruption and violence at every level.

This incident is likely a symptom of a much greater issue in Slovakia: widespread corruption and ties to organized crime. Ties to an Italian crime group is probably the tip of the ice berg, with corrupt business bosses across Slovakia getting cozy with international gangsters and ordering hits to protect their interests. Like an ant you find in your house, there is never just the one, and so it is with corporate corruption. Slovaks must demand further investigation and better policing.

This is probably just one step to what is needed to take down the criminal orgs there. The police need to focus on the big players like the politicians before going after who they hire to do their dirty work. Arresting the powerful people getting away with getting people to do their work is much more important that the people being hired.

I agree that this is the right direction! More criminals that order murders should be brought to justice. I just wonder how many innocent people are being convicted of crimes due to corrupt figures being able to pay off the right people. We should be aiming for more thorough investigations and should not lose the sight that everyone is innocent until proven guilty. It's the core belief of the whole judicial system.

I think if you're running a country like this, you either criminalize investigative reporting like the kind done by Kuciak, or you allow it but make no guarantees about the personal safety of such journalists. You can either make it impossible for them to get themselves killed or you can strongly discourage them from engaging in work that might get themselves killed. What other options could there be?
This is absurd! The person charged was in a position of power. Authority is always right!

This is a good step towards justice. Imagine how much worse things could get if these elite figures were shown they could literally get away with murder. What today is an extraordinary killing that causes shockwaves across all of the country could soon become just another mundane murder with impunity by the rich that happens all the time, because they know they can get away with it.

To answer your question, there are definitely more options to fixing the problem than the two you listed. The idea that we should criminalize investigative reporting or just leave the reporters on their own is baffling. How about we allow all reporting and we protect the media from physical attacks? The government should pass more laws protecting the right of the media and free speech, they also should enhance the laws ensuring the media is not under threat from criminals. Jan Kuciak and Martina Kusnirova had their lives ended tragically, we cannot bring them back, but we can pay tribute to them by protecting others that follow in their footsteps. Don't you feel that is a good idea?

If the people and journalists aren't even being allowed to get the specific details of the case or attend the press conferences and whatnot, eventually this'll just lead to the government never telling the people anything. They will first just give the bare minimum info and then nothing at all. Once a government feels comfortable leaving their people in the dark, they will never give up that power.

I think it's more that they're celebrating the fact that someone so powerful is actually being held accountable. Whether they're ultimately found to be guilty or not is one thing, but the mere fact that they've been arrested is progress. It reassures the public that the rich and powerful aren't above the law, and justice reaches everyone.

So if you are arrested in Japan you are held under "hostage justice" until you confess.  That seems to me like torturing prisoners until they confess.  I guess in Japan, you are guilty until proven innocent the reverse of the US justice system.  I don't see how a coerced confession can even be tried fairly.

Ghost is a foreigner who headed a Japanese company and ended up in trouble with the Japanese government and now has escaped which makes for a dangerous precedent for the Japanese judicial system. What happens if other people try it? How many other foreigners in Japan may be doing things considered illegal only to the japanese? Could they perhaps attempt to escape? It could end up influencing Japanese natives to do the same. This could make Japan look bad.

He wasn't a saviour but I also like to see sometimes that people can work around the system to get their freedom. Reminds me of the stories my granddad told me about people outsmarting the man during prohibition. The good thing is the holes he used for deception will be plugged so the system should be better in the end.

Regardless of what issues Japan's legal system may have, this is not good news. First, big-time rich Europeans escape the law. Then it'll be the rich locals. Then the middle class. Finally, everyone will be able to just flee and the legal system has basically collapsed. Imagine the chaos and anarchy that will overtake the country. All kicked off by some rich European's escape that some people actually thought was a good thing.

Everyone who knows about Japans criminal justice system knows its insane and should be illegal. Even the tough on crime people in the US would say their process for holding suspects with no bail, indefinitely is absurd. He had every right to escape. I've read about this before and all the commenters agree that their system is BROKEN.

Even if the system is broken does  that make it okay to just commit a crime and leave the country? He still needs to pay for his crimes. This sets a dangerous precedent. Instead there needs to be justice system reform.

Saying things like that will eventually lead you and others to being happy when all criminals get out of their punishment. That thinking will lead to lawlessness. I mean, if you are happy one tax evader escaped justice, why wouldn't you be happy when a robber or a murderer escaped next?

If the system was not innocent until proven guilty, do you think they would have given him bail and let him out on house arrest? To me that seems like they were going to let him at least have a say in court. Even Japanese legal scholar Ichiro Suzuki has come out and said that the Japanese judicial system is lax, especially for the wealthy. So that should be an indication that defendant had rights and was granted them.
This is unreal, the stuff of novels and movies. Sad to hear about all the dysfunction though, and the lack of due process must be tough on Japanese citizens, especially when they're innocent.

Can't say I'm surprised by this, at least when it comes to the nature of the Japanese justice system. Anytime I see an article on the subject, it's always talking about how harsh and unfair it is. The simple fact I've never seen anything good written about it probably suggests it's irredeemable. I hope Japan is able to do something about this.

There's no justification for his escape; by doing so, it makes his guilt more apparent.  It is obvious that Japan's justice system needs significant reform but he wasn't Robin Hood. He committed serious crimes and needs to face the consequences. His position as a 'corporate titan' does not excuse his actions nor allow him to get away with what he has done.  Taking advantage of Japan's two-tiered justice system doesn't show any sort of superiority or 'right' - it's just another crime he needs to answer for.

This incident, innocuous as it is, does raise awareness regarding the importance of the simplest aspects of cyber security, like solid passwords, etc. However, the national economy, COVID, and other factors seem like much more urgent foci for the government's attention. Sure, shore up your passwords and do what should be done to keep the network secure, but let's direct time and energy to the more central things: economy, healthcare, geopolitical issues, etc.

What's with all the baseless speculation? It was the opposition, Greeks, Russians, etc., etc. Seemingly with no evidence for any of them being the culprits. Seems smarter to not just throw out every name out there and cause unnecessary derision towards whatever group.

No one wants to be on the end of compromised data and information targeted by hackers so of course, downplaying the seriousness of this is typical. It's a good thing however that this incident is leading to perhaps making sure that it doesn't happen again. If this is a wakeup call that prompts improvement in cybersecurity measures, like implementing stronger encryption or bolstering network firewalls, then at least some good can come out of it.

Hackers need to be dealt with in a strict and harsh manner as there is no telling what damage they could one day cause. If you make hackers scared of getting caught due to the harsh consequences there will be less of them willing to risk their freedom. At least that is what I believe would happen if the consequences where harsh.

It doesn't seem healthy to me that everything these days gets blamed on insidious foreign actors, whether that be Russia or China or whoever. Seems like an easy scapegoat governments can just constantly use anytime they've done something wrong. Next thing you know, people will be blaming the Kremlin when they stub their toe on a door.

Completely agree! When things like this happen, it is so easy to rush to the opposition like the Greeks or Russians and that rises and unhealthy stereotype. Everyone always suspects those groups to always be behind malice activity and it's often not the case. Each incident should be evaluated on its own merits. However, it seems that people have a tendency to prematurely blame certain groups without sufficient evidence. It's an unfair and unhealthy practice that we should all strive to change. We should educate ourselves and others about the importance of avoiding snap judgements like this.

It is great that no real information appears to have been stolen. It seems this is a good time for everyone to look at their own cyber security. People need to make sure they have password and virus protection and protect sensitive information. It does seem that on average that people understand the importance of cyber security.

It's justified that the people think that data has been stolen.  It could have very well been taken and the data that was taken has not been identified yet.   I think it's natural to make this assumption.  I just assume these days that some has my data or information and do my best to keep tabs on it.

When I see a major hacking story like this, I immediately become doubtful of all the details that come from parties that are directly involved in the incident. Should we just buy automatically what these biased individuals release to the public? I think not. What we need here is an independent security firm to come in and see what damage was actually done. Too expensive? Not needed? I highly disagree with this and so does Tom Stayward of Tom's Cybersecurity Plus. He is an expert of internet security and he says they must hire a team of experts to check into this matter. Furthermore he is no slouch in the field, he has investigated numerous such incidents and has found the root truths in all of them. He says 'It's often not what the officials first believe, many times there are breeches they don't even know have happened." I know some people will just want to move on, but I feel we must find the truth. Is anything more important than the truth?

I'm not surprised that this blew up.  Government cybersecurity is terrible in general,  but much worse are stupid script kiddies who can't even do proper social engineering.  A skilled hacker wouldn't have had difficulty getting into the system, that's the scary thing. Cybersecurity is deficient across most governments.    Everyone needs o put more effort into it.

It seems like the government is addressing bigger problems. The hack wasn't serious, they took some steps to bolster security anyway, and then went about doing the government's business. I understand why the opposition party and others may want to inflate the importance of the event, but the government at least realizes that there are more pressing issues.

It is natural that the government would deny that the cyberattacks have been successful. I wouldn't trust what they say, to be honest. If the attacks had been successful, it would have been perfectly natural for the government to refute it, in order to cover up their own incompetence in the matter. Self preservation at its best.

I like the fact that the artist is able to take both the good and bad from her homelands history and turn it into beautiful and meaningful artwork. I think this is a way to engage the audience in a way that will be profound. I think that we can all agree that art can help us confront and heal from our past.

Staring at slavery feels like people think black people should sit and stare at the past. And relive traumatic events? People used to understand what had happened, and live with it without constantly bringing it up. The people now are not as strong as previous generations. At least not emotionally.

The use of natural elements in her work is inspiring. More artists should focus on using the things the world has gifted us instead of all these modern day, computer assisted works. Art is so much more meaningful when it's made of the raw materials the Earth has gifted us rather than some synthetic stuff.

I agree, with the natural elements are great and stick out more. It gives it a better view of how it looks and what it was like. The nature is beautiful and has the history of what it was like, it's great to preserve what it was like so they'll know where they came from.

Though it is necessary to discuss and dissect historical times to understand our present I think people need to not dwell too much on our past mistakes. People who talk about colonial past need to focus on the future instead to move forward. They should not be stuck in the past in order to make progress.
There's always an issue to explore. Art can be good and sometimes bad. That means, if it fixates too much on past evils, like slavery, the beauty can be lost. Leading to a resentment of art.

Why focus on the traumatic past of colonial times with your art? You could make an actual difference if you used your art to bring attention to important issues of today! I'm sure your home country is still not in great shape after all! Like Banksy, for instance: He uses art to wake people up to modern issues like war and economic problems!
Art is either abstract or impactful. I think her art leans to the latter. She can harness traumatic colonial past experiences to express a pain and emotion.

For too long many have tried to avoid the ugly truth of the past. I am glad that someone is exploring it through their art and reminding us about some dark sides of history. This is the best way to get us to acknowledge and learn from it. Artistic exploration has always been a powerful tool that we can use to discuss our past.

This artist is striking in her expressions, both artistic and verbal. I haven't read an interview involving such sophisticated language (used by an artist) in quite some time. She is likely a fascinating person to have a conversation with. And the range and depth of her artistic vision are inspiring.

Are you saying that abstract art can't have an impact? I have to disagree there for sure, as many people, myself included, have been impacted by abstract works. In fact, based on the descriptions of Thomas-Girvan's work, much of it can be said to be abstract. We can often be heavily impacted when our mind fills in the blanks of what the artist really wants to represent or say.

That is what is neat about art. People can look at it and take different things away from it. I am sure that there may be some people that are not aware of the history of the Caribbean islands and works like this one may be an avenue for people to understand the roads that led to the way the region operates now, and not some fairy tale. It is good to remind the people of the past so bad things that happened do not happen again for instance. Not every culture has a fairy tale history to fall back on and remember fondly. This artist is taking an opportunity to educate and remind people of not only what has happened, but what CAN happen even though hard times came before, without buffering it or softening it to comfort the masses. It is inspirational in my opinion to see this artist take such care to do such a thing that way. It gives people a glimpse into how the Caribbean that we know today got to where it is.

Regardless of where a person comes from, if they are causing no harm to society then they should be left alone to live their lives. Treating them in a racist manner is simply a poor reflection on you, and your country. Everyone should strive to be better. We need to show the younger generation a better way so this does not continue.

The families of the victims in this travesty should continue to seek justice against those who committed those crimes. The government allowed this violence to play to some extend it appears. I feel more investigation is needed before this is pinned solely on the government.

I don't think people should focus so much on the past. Both Indonesia and China have a lot of significant problems they're facing right now. There's ever-increasing repression in both countries, inequality, suffering of all kinds. Is now the time to try to heal the wounds of some 25 year old event that affected some small minority? That is the sort of thing you try to do after you've solved the bigger problems.
I think this is a fallacy-just because it is in the past does not mean it is not important and should not be a focus even if there are other problems at the present. This is important to the people.

This was an isolated event in response to a 30 year old rule of one autocrat.  It was not reflective of a cultural value of racial prejudice against Chinese in Indonesia.  This should not happen in a functioning democracy and the problems should not lead to this. For example it has not happened again since then and the problem has not come up before.  So no need to bring it up and push the issue.

Not acknowledging past wrongs is a dangerous game to play. By ignoring these types of events we leave the door open for them to occur again. We need to remember the past so we can learn from it and do better in the future. Ignoring one event leads to ignoring more events and eventually ending up with even worse consequences in the future.
This is a powerful piece. The story told lets the history live on so that those in the present can learn from it,

There is a standardized pattern of government bullying. They will use proxy elements to carry this out. They try to hide behind street urchins and such to destabilize their own society and the people in it.

I am struggling to understand why you think that we can only address one issue at a time, this is not the way the world has to work. This brave woman has come forward to share her story and this should not be overlooked or silenced. It does not matter how long ago this event happened, people from that time surely still wear the scars from those days. I think by hearing from these people that we can bring closure to their suffering and hopefully give other people the strength to come forward with their own stories. That is how we can fight current repression around the world, this is how we will show that justice is possible when we recognize problems from any time. I thought she did a great job in this article and I am interested to learn more about her and her story. Anyone else feel this way?

I disagree. As they say, those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. This is a powerful story that is both a testament to a horrible episode in history, and a warning to readers about what can happen to vulnerable groups when the power structure of a society is in flux. It's not just dwelling on a past event in one country--it's a lesson for all societies to help them not repeat such mistakes. I'm happy it's available digitally so it can reach a global audience. You should check it out: www.thechinesewhispers.com/en/

I think something you may be missing here, is that by fixing this problem, it helps lead to fixing those other problems you see as important. If people can come to terms with something that harmed a minority several years ago, it can help start healing some of that inequality and suffering. People working together to get past differences is what will bring solutions to the problems you mentioned. Turning a blind eye to the events of the past only drive a larger wedge between the people that were harmed and the damage done by the terrible actions of the Indonesians that perpetrated them. It could lead to the events being repeated, which would be an even greater tragedy. This digital novel does a great job of reminding people exactly what happened and why it should not happen again.
This is an amazing and exciting find. I am sorry to hear about the people dying from snake bites though. Hopefully they will develop effective ways of preventing or dealing with that, and soon.

This is interesting news, hope to see a video of it or something. And I didn't really think of how crucial snakes are to their ecosystems, but Mr. Devkota makes it clear why they are. Though I wonder about the farming point. I want to look up more on that from other experts too as I would have imagined they're more a net negative in that aspect.

If we are finding two headed snakes then there must be something in the water, I bet man is polluting the area. There is no other possible answer. When weird shit happens, its always us that causes it.

The article claims the snake is rare in Nepal, but given the villagers just randomly came across the snake (no indication they were hunting or search for it), then surely it's more common than is supposed here. In fact, it's probably the case that a massive number of these snakes are living in the region, as that would explain how a random person who isn't even looking for one just happened to come across it.

The main subject is definitely interesting, but I didn't know snakes were so important to the ecosystem. I hope the country is able to make sure they keep thriving, it seems like their only real option. Without them, there will just be pests all over.

I agree, seeing a two headed snake must be quite the impression! Honestly, things like this happen in nature due to unforeseen reasons. Pollution or something being dumped in the water wouldn't warrant this kind of change in so few snakes. Remember, there are only a few cases like this in the area. If it was pollution changing things, it would be more wide spread and in different areas. A possible cause to this could just be inbreeding. We're talking a few snakes, not even a few hundred. However, Davis, you are correct about the effects of pollution  but that can take upwards of years to manifest. Let's not blow things out of proportion and assume that every new oddity of nature is a direct result of pollution. Nature is just full of surprises sometimes!

Not to sound overly skeptical here, but so many stats are given in this article (survival rates, incident rates, etc.) and yet not one of them is backed up by any sort of citation or reference to an authoritative source. Without that it's hard to just accept these "facts" in an uncritical way.

While the main subject is interesting, I'm more concerned with the threat to the snakes in general. More must be done to protect them, for the sake of the ecosystem. If we don't ramp up protection efforts, they'll surely slip into extinction. And then that will just lead to greater collapse in the ecosystem as a whole.

I agree, it is very odd to find two-headed snakes in the same area. It reminds me of research that Dr. Jake Jacobson has done over the years. He had published a famed paper on this subject about how the water is so contaminated that there was traces of nuclear waste. I agreed with him until Janie Janet released her evidence against there being any nuclear waste in the water there. It's hard to believe that Jacobson knows what he is talking about when he claims such a thing that can easily be proven wrong. Comparing both conclusions, you really don't know what to believe. I guess we need more studies on the topic. I wonder if there are other tests out there that can be done?

It seems that they are already working to protect the snakes. The article states there are many benefits to having snakes around, especially for farmers. It seems snakes already have a tradition of helping the people and will continue to do so for a long time.

We must do more to protect snakes in the wild, too many are killed by humans that unnecessarily fear them. We also must do more to educate people on how to behave around them and ensure neither party ends up injured. While I agree with you on that aspect, I don't agree with you that this issue is sure to lead the greater ecosystem to collapse. Fear mongering is not necessary and will likely turn people away from the issue completely. All people need to understand is how integral they are to controlling major pests, do you know anyone who likes rodent invasions? I have yet to meet the person who does and this is a key element to winning support for protecting all snake species. Education, not fear, is always the best tactic to gain support for any critical issue. I hope that we all can do our part to ensure snakes are here and thriving in the years to come.

The ecosystem needs to be preserved, and we as humans should take better care of everything around us. The banded kukri snake, along with all other wildlife, plays an essential role that shouldn't be undermined. It's incredibly fascinating to see such rare conditions as dicephaly occurring in nature. Big thanks to all the passionate people like Mr. Devkota working tirelessly on human-snake conflict mitigation!

We need to work hard to eradicate all forms of domestic violence, pandemic induced or otherwise. The experts have made it clear that aside from the basic human rights issues involved, this kind of violence just hurts everyone in the community and makes everything worse. Like Joyce Banda said, the seeds of success in every nation on Earth are best planted in women and children.

I wouldnât be surprised if the suicide rates of women in those countries was at an all time high too. Itâs either live in fear or risk even more violence if you try to get help. We need to be addressing the issue of violence against women that was already there long before COVID.#Itstimeforachange

This issue, particularly on the gender gap, is undeniably a crucial matter that requires effort not only from leaders but from every individual as well. I'm reminded of a great philosopher I once looked up to, Aristotle, who asserted that components of the society ought to be treated on equal grounds. Despite him living eons ago, his ideas are still relevant and insightful to this day. While it can't be ignored that there are inherent biological differences between genders, that ought not to translate into disparities in societal opportunities and treatment. This renders Aristotle's notions even more significant as they underline the need for every individual, irrespective of their gender, to be on equal ground.

Governments and law enforcement agencies need to step up and protect women across the globe but especially in the more middle eastern societies. Women are not safe at home, especially now and they need to be able to speak up and be protected. As well as a global society we need men to learn to stop abusing women. Men and women alike need to be educated about violence and the damage it does to generations.

This is terrible and something that needs to be addressed immediately. It's obvious that most people, if not nearly all, are totally against domestic violence, so why is it still such a widespread problem? The government needs to listen to the majority and do something about this. We can't keep ignoring it.

100% agreed! Suicide rates and the violence against women needs to be looked at. Have you considered the domestic violence against men in this situation? The focus is always on the women who are battered by their partners but the number one reason of suicide for men is domestic violence with 1 out of 7 men (that's 13.8%) have been assaulted by their partners at some point in their life per NCADV. This is something we need to look at closely and carefully because it is an alarming statistic. Sure, traditionally speaking, domestic violence has long been associated with female victims. That's not incorrect, there are way too many of those but it's not completely correct and cover the whole scope of domestic violence victims. We need to hear from all victims, men and women. Doing it will not discredit the female voices, but will enrich the concept of justice when we see all sexes be held accountable.  This battle should be a shared one so no one is left behind and all voices are heard loud and clear!

If women are not able to leave their homes due to the pandemic then the authorities and the governments need to work together to make sure that children and families are safe. There needs to be resources available to these people and also help for men that think abuse is common and normal. There are large problems in the world but its okay to start with issues at home.

While it breaks the heart to hear of the suffering endured by these women, an even greater threat against them, also produced by their traditional androcentric society, looms even more darkly: honor killings. In southern Asia and parts of MENA honor killings are normalized, and women live in terror. It would be nice if activist groups would target that behavior and condemn it, and then perhaps move on to issues like domestic abuse and gender equality.

The abuse it heartbreaking to hear about no matter who is happens too. I wish there was more being done about this in the Middle East. Renowned author and Middle East expert, Hans Christians, has a book about this topic where he says that it is a generational issue that will never be changed since it is ingrained with religion. He's not religious, so I am not sure what he would know about anything ingrained in the religion so how can we trust what he says? One would think that a cultural shift would end all the violence. In contrast, an Islamic religion expert and devote Islamic follower, Ali Mustafa, claims it is not solely a generational problem but an education and opportunity issue. His perspective, although different, seems to carry more weight. Isn't it apt to believe that a man who lives within the system could provide more insight on how the system works?

Unfortunately,  the pandemic is just exacerbating existing issues,  rather than creating new ones.    Preventing this requires a complete change in how these cultures view women,  and that's not an easy solution to implement.   Real change can really only come from giving women and equal role in these societies and normalizing such equality.    Laws protecting the rights of women and encouraging their participation in the workforce would be a good start,  but it's a long and difficult road.

Governments really need to address these issues before they get worse. The rises in the rates, as horrible as they are, aren't nearly as bad as they can and likely will get if nothing is done. Eventually, there won't be a single woman out there who hasn't been a victim of domestic violence. The entire basic family structure could be so irreversibly harmed. This is a real threat to the future of humanity.

Domestic violence is never justified. It is particularly heartbreaking to hear that more women are suffering from domestic violence due to the COVID lockdown. The government should be doing more to help these women.

The legalization of pepper spray for use by women for self-protection sounds like a good idea, sure, but Jamaica must be careful. Taking this line can lead to unforeseen consequences, as things can get out of control very quickly. First, they will be given the right to use pepper spray, but what comes after that? Perhaps blackjacks. And then? Maybe tasers. And after that? Probably guns. And then there would be a troubling new layer of violence in Jamaica. This kind of approach to solving problems can evolve rapidly and get away from you, eventually creating a whole new set of problems. I'm not saying pepper spray is a bad idea, just that caution is highly advised.

In almost every culture, it is essentially a tradition to make men fear ever laying hands on a woman. Jamaica needs to make an example out of any man who does. Don't hold back at all. The violence will stop after enough see what can happen to them. It has always been unacceptable to harm a woman, but nowadays its less so. Take us back to those days!

Completely!  Music and art are used as a mirror to society echoing the reality that many live in and see. It's merely bringing a spotlight to it so it can be more known.  It does seem like an easy scapegoat, but turning a blind eye to the root cause doesn't solve anything. If we want to see a change in the lyrics, the society needs to change first. Poverty, racial inequality, crime rates, and for Jamaica, femicide should all be what we focus on changing.The focus should be on this societal issue and not a Beanie Man song.

It's pretty clear that the vast majority of people feel that abusing women is wrong. These types of stories are very sad because mostly everyone agrees that the violence against women needs to stop. When will all stand up and raises our voices against this senseless abuse? We also must talk seriously with the few people that oppose this for whatever misguided reason they have. It's only with efforts like these will women be safe again.

This is the result of an extremely sexist culture. I doubt many of the men and boys there were ever taught how to respect women. Is there really any other explanation considering these women are all being killed by men?
Its clear that something must be done, but no one is doing it. We have a government, we must hold them accountable and force them to act. Everyone must speak up, it could be someone you love next.
It's the norm for people to blame songs. While ignoring self-blame. Lyrics are only as powerful as the weakness of who is listening. So it's not the song's fault.

If men can't protect women and the government can't protect their people, what good are they? Men have always protected women, and governments have always existed to protect their people. The Jamaican government and Jamaican men are failing here. If Jamaica wants to become a safer place, they need to stick to the traditions of men and government protecting their women.

They should choose a religious figure to find a solution this problem of violence against women in Jamaica.  Who could be a better authority to decide such a thing other than a man of God?  It would help these women certainly.  But since not everyone follow the same religion, we should consult a diverse group of people including women.

Totally unacceptable to see the rising murder rates in Jamaica and they were already the highest in Latin America previously. This needs to be stopped and it needs to be stopped quickly. I was a bit bewildered by the idea of legalizing pepper spray as some sort of fix for this problem. I understand that we want to give women the right to defend themselves, but I feel like there are much bigger issues to deal with first. How about actually getting to the root of the problem that is causing all these murders? We need to create a whole range of programs that address violence and allows us to learn how this problem is engrained in the society at a young age. We all can be a part of this solution, by talking to those around us and making sure that everyone learns through love and empathy. The pepper spray is a quick fix and it may have its place eventually, but lets hit this major problem first.

I'd be interested in statistics on other Caribbean countries and territories, given the high (and rising) rate of violence against women in Jamaica. Given that the rate is high and rising in that country, you can believe it's also high and rising in most, if not all, of the other Caribbean countries. Let's hope for positive changes, and soon.

I think the fact that a lady was murdered is kind of being buried here by political issues and people trying to make a name for themselves. More needs to be done here. Where is law enforcement here to help?

I understand that everyone wants women to be treated correctly and with respect. We also must listen to them when they speak about the behaviors that they are dealing with from men. With that said, we need to be careful that we don't to our due diligence and investigate these accusations. So these three men who has questionable behaviors should be looked into and dealt with is it is found to be true. So lets listen to all sides and learn the facts of the stories to make sure we get them right.

Everyone knows men who have a history of sexual violence can not be trusted, and that goes double for if they are politicians. Its absurd to let a man like that become one. It goes against the tradition of being able to trust your public officials. Politicians have always been supposed to meet higher moral standards than the rest of us. Being a woman abuser is disqualifying.

I think that taking allegations of sexual misconduct into account, instead of actual convictions, is not a wise move. This could lead to innocent politicians being slandered and removed from office, over false allegations, which happen a lot. This could be used by political opponents to remove candidates from an election a false allegation of sexual misconduct.

Women should be more open to the tradition of men governing. In this case there would not be these dilemmas. Civilizations have thrived under this type of system. Let us uphold customs and  achieve stability and continuity.
Most can agree sexual harassment is bad. So most will agree it is right to ban them from office. This is a way to keep the majority of society safe from predatory people being in positions of power.

It seems that you didn't Tobago's election process needs to be overhauled. I'm not sure how far they have to go, but it seems like there are some things that need to be addressed. Every political candidate should have their background apparently inspected. This could lead to a more trustworthy political process for those countries.

It is one of the oldest traditions in the world to elect people to office who the public can trust. If you are someone who has sexual assault allegations, you are not trustworthy and electing you would break that tradition. If they think its okay to run with these allegations, which other traditions would they break/

There are only two reasons for this. Women want control, not equality. The aggressive demands like a change in constitution is a bit odd. Sure, they should do something, but maybe a bit down to earth.

This type of law does not allow the legal court process to decide the issue. These political candidates have not been found guilty of a crime. These candidates are innocent of any allegations, unless proven guilty. It is unfair to political candidates to bypass the courts, and punish them.

I think if someone is accused of sexual assault or something, that shouldn't disqualify them from running, but if they are CONVICTED of it, then of course they should be disqualified. That is just common sense. You can't have someone like that representing a country. Its good these women are trying to get some meaningful change done!

You really think this is them wanting control, by barring sex offenders from running for office? Plenty of countries bar people convicted of some crimes from office. I don't think this is particularly unreasonable, and if their proposals go through, I don't think women will have more 'control' in any negative way.

It seems like this area of the world has had years and years where this kind of behavior was tolerated and things ran smoothly. I see no reason why anyone would want to make drastic changes just to suit some special interest group. Even if people may question them due to their accusations that does not necessarily mean that they would make bad leaders and that is what past elections have allowed people to decide about the character of leader they want. Look at the success of Bill Clinton in the US. He is hailed a great American president that served two terms after having multiple charges of improper relationships with women. "If the wagon runs fine, why change the wheels?", like my grandfather used to say.
If the rapes happen, then there should be protests. If they are false, there should be allegations. These days, everything is rape. Physical contact.. rape. Eye contact... rape.

It's great to see that these people are creating truly meaningful art. Expressing meaningful opinions in the hopes of changing hearts and minds is one of the most innate, natural and human things there is. Hopefully the leaders of these lagging governments will also tap into the natural desire to help people around them and make their surroundings better, for the sake of themselves if not the well-being of all the women being harmed.

Professor Rita Laura Segato understands the broader implications of the individual interaction. And women are being abused all over the world in a number of ways. Mostly by the system in which we live. I wonder what she would suggest as a way to address the issue.
There are issues like wars going on. While this is important, it comes second. Victims should get justice, but equitably.

This is a great message and I hope everyone takes it to heart. As our greatest minds have repeatedly pointed out, sexism and discrimination is bad for everyone. And it's not an anti-man thing at all. As Laura Bates pointed out, it's not a men versus women issue. It's a people versus prejudice issue.

If we continue to turn a deaf ear, we are indirectly encouraging the oppression of women on a global scale, leading eventually to a society where gender discrimination is the norm. We have to realize that this would undermine the progress we've made in the fight for gender equality, leading to deep-rooted disparities and conflicts. If we don't act now and pressurize our governments to formulate and enforce laws to protect the rights of these women, it could lead to a world marked by increasing social unrest and deep divides. Ignoring this problem is like setting off a chain reaction that continues to marginalize half of the world's population, pushing us all the way back to the dark ages of total inequality.

Completely absolving responsibility of maintaining safety practices doesn't help either. Women need to realize they should also take precautions. Expecting that a flashmob will stop bad guys from being bad guys is naive.

While everyone obviously opposes plain rape and the like, a lot of people try to downplay and dismiss the root causes of these things, saying that it's natural for men to have some power over women. It is not. What's truly natural is these people's desires to be free and secure, regardless of their gender. That is the real fundamental part of humanity, and we should focus on that and respect those rights.

so much attention is drawn when there is an allegation or accusation. this makes it hard because it brings so much attention and provides an easy out for someone to falsely accuse someone. there should be harsh penalties for women who make false allegations for one reason or the other.

There are worse problems then a false allegations, and its true allegations that are never seen. There needs to be effort to see the true ones through. There needs to be a system to ensure justice for victims of abuse without getting drowned out in the noise of false claims.

It would be nice to see this social media phenomenon parlay into legislation and a cleanup of corrupt governments. That is the idea, right? Eventually, flash mob videos can lead to real solid change reaching all the way to the top, yielding stricter laws and more ethical governments.
I think anything that empowers women like this is a good thing. It's also peaceful and no one is harmed in the process

The Madagascar child protection network of 750 members has been unable to make enough progress in ending child violence in the country, and will continue on like this without action. We need to do away with the program if it continues this lack of progress, because it will continue to fail at it's objectives.

Do children deserve to be protected or harmed?  It is shocking that this is happening to these unfortunate children.  It is a natural state that children are to be loved and protected, not harmed by their care takers.  Mothers usually have an inborn need to protect their offspring, hormones can be a very powerful evolutionary force.  We should step in now that we know this is happening and get these children out.  How far should we go to help these children?  As much as they need us to.

There seems to be too much first world perspective in this argument. Life is rough on the third world and blindly applying child rights from our perspective will lead to worse problems for them. I understand the emotional appeal to things such as beating children and making them work for low pay but you can't just wave a wand from an economic standpoint and make this better like that

Some of this is just their culture's way of educating and disciplining. Having a foreign company step in will go from just trying to reduce abuse to eventually trying to control the government and imposing their values on them. Its a form of colonialism to have us tell them how to raise their kids or teach their kids. It could lead to the loss of their own cuture.

Its quite appalling that children in Madagascar are being exploited and traumatized because its government is doing nothing about it. Its embarrassing, wrong and disgusting. There should be some kind of oversight committee in that country that protects children from these harmful situations.

It's strange that this article tries to point to their traditions as something bad that they should abandon. Traditions become traditions for a reason, and if corporal punishment is part of their traditions, then there was a good reason for it. And I don't think foreigners should be able to dictate that they abandon their traditions either.

No one wants to see children hurt. I think anyone would say stopping this violence is important. This is a worldwide issue. I am sure the general consensus is children should never have violence perpetuated against them. We cannot use claims of tradition to continue this. If tradition is the excuse then these traditions need to end.

Basically you are saying that we should just turn a blind eye to children being abused? No child in any part of the world should be subjected to physical, sexual or mental abuse. For you to deem that as something that is a first world problem, is very ignorant. Yes, some of these behaviors stem from culture and tradition, it is still wrong for us not to try and mitigate the situation. It's time that we broader our perspective and face these challenges head on. Its much better than to just stand by and make comments that can be deemed as ignorant.

I agree with you completely. Plus, people are acting like they should abandon their traditions. Of course, the extreme forms of violence and sexual exploitation that some kids experience are terrible, but things like kids working in the family business or mild corporal punishment is just something ingrained in many cultures and that's their right.

Identifying the problem is only an initial step. Now we must act to resolve this crisis (a crisis is what it is). Let's unite our voices and support those in Madagascar who will advocate for the children. Let's hope international organizations ramp up their support of local initiatives.

This is something that should be the country's main concern. Pretty much every country on earth knows how wrong it is to hurt kids and yet the majority of this country's kids are hurt and exploited? What is wrong with them? Obviously I'm not saying all countries need to act and think just like us in all respects, but this is one thing that absolutely should be.

Corporal punishment used to be entirely normal in America as well. Can we really judge them for the same traditions that we also had up until very recently? It really is a challenge, as the article notes, for such deep-rooted tradition to be broken. We should offer our help, not make any judgments.

This situation is absolutely appalling. Swift action must be taken against those in power before the entire society breaks down. Changes in law enforcement and public punishments should be enacted quickly. It makes one wonder if it would be preferable to completely abolish the law enforcement agencies and let everyone fend for themselves.

Well this is deeply disturbing. When you grant the police permission to commit violence against citizens, you find out what kind of policemen you have. It sounds like a nightmare. Nothing short of a complete overhaul of the system is warranted.

I hope their country is able to stand up and depose Duterte for good. If they don't, I fear these trends will only continue. Things will just get worse and dozens of these horrendous crimes will turn into hundreds, then more. There's no alternative but getting an actually decent leader.

If the police are allowed to get away with such heinous crimes against people then what is to stop them from doing more? What is to stop anyone from doing whatever they feel if even the police and the president are ok with crimes like rape and abuse?  The country will fall into anarchy and will lead to mass government corruption and death.

This is tough since you need a tough police force in order to run a country and keep law and order. Duterte can either continue to encourage coarseness and brio among his policemen, seeing these cases of rape as an unfortunate byproduct of tough policing by tough cops, or he can cleanse the police departments and rebuild the force de novo. I don't think a third way, that of reform, will be very effective.

In authoritarian countries like this, police just always get away with their crimes. Even though it might have gotten worse under Duterte, the underlying problem has existed for as long as any of us have. It's going to be very hard for things to change given how normal some of these abuses have been. Hopefully they can put a lid on it and change things.

Whatever the majority of the populace thinks is going on in the police force is probably correct. Mass formation of thoughts is often true. Such a large grouping can't be wrong, there must be a form of truth to it.

This is just one more case that proves that police are all pretty awful people. The politicians who support them are almost worse. They allow these crimes against women and children to go unchecked. This is such a troubling case and you have to wonder how many more there have been that have gone unreported.

I agree that there must be action by Duterte over these appalling crimes, I just think a more nuanced approach would work better. There are definitely more than just two approaches to help fix the police force in the Philippines. Clear and comprehensive training for police officers would be the obvious first step, followed by a ongoing program that monitors any violations as they occur. Also it would be wise to being hiring officers from a varied sample of the population, this way we have more representation and can help prevent problems before they happen. I think implementing these are a good step forward to cleaning up the police and still having a strong force going forward.

Not always.  You're making a hasty generalization.   It's rare for authoritarians to hold their own forces to real standards,  but they sometimes do.  After all,   it's not good to be hated.     Smart authoritarians know to clad the iron fist in a velvet glove, and bring the hammer down on real abuses.  You can't really judge all of them by the actions of one.  
Duarte hasn't read The Prince,  unfortunately.   He's just a thug in a suit,  a tough guy who doesn't understand how to really rule.   He shouldn't brush these atrocities under the rug,   and nor should we.  We should continue to raise awareness.   To demand accountability.    No one should be above the law.

The President has said that he will take responsibility for the rape cases of his troops. I am sure that as President, he would know best. However, judging from the macho culture he is cultivating, I highly doubt that any rape victims would see any real justice done under him.

The people of the Philippines should do everything in their power to stop Duerte.  The rape and violence shouldn't be a part of their daily lives.  Innocent people don't deserve this.  It's scary that it's people in the government who are encouraging and allowing this. The international human rights community should take action and use their voices for the voiceless.

In the Donbas area of Ukraine as in many areas of the world where there is conflict, there is little trust in the government and more interest in personal survival than there is in politics. Foment is often the result when government does not respond to the needs of the people it governs. Basically people are much more interested in personal survival rather than politics. If things are bad, there is distrust in the government.

This isn't surprising to me really. What other choice do these people truly have? They don't have any real control over their governments. Their choices are either to leave their homelands, or just accept whatever comes their way. There isn't any meaningful alternative for them.

All in all, really interesting with what is happening in Donbas. It's going to be historically interesting what will happen with DNR/LNR as he country and area progresses. Either way, the geopolitical implications would be considerable. What is that going to mean for the state of international relations? Only time can tell, I guess.

I get that the author/s of this article conducted their surveys, but something important is missing here. There is no certification of these findings (and more importantly, their meaning) by an expert on the local politics of the region. Without that it's difficult to onboard these "results" with anything more than skepticism. If they had recruited someone like Professor Z, who is actually from the region himself, into the project, then I would more readily accept these findings.

Of course these people don't really care all that much about what flag is above the government buildings. Actual security and prosperity is much more important to most. Both sides should tone down the nationalist rhetoric and focus on what actually matters - the well-being of the people.

Coming from what I have gleaned myself, and considering the folks who are directly affected by this ongoing conflict, it's simple human nature that trust will just erode over time. The dreadful experience of every time the sun sets, all the combat and fear just wears people down imperceptibly. This isn't a reflection on their patriotism but rather a tough reality. Can't blame them after all, when it comes to their own safety and the safety of their loved ones, everyone seemingly puts their livelihood over nationalism. Hard confrontations foster hard decisions, sadly.

Like many other folks here, I'm not surprised by these results. It would be difficult to trust a government after so much discord. But that's what democratic systems are about -- change. Hopefully the upcoming elections can bring about some much-needed change and restore some faith of the citizens. Areas affecting individual outcomes need attention: things like the economy, education, and health services for example. The current state is disheartening, but we can remain optimistic about the future.

Governments as a whole cannot be trusted to do the right thing by the people but for themselves to stay in power. If you live in a war zone it must be hard to believe that your government cares about your safety and wellbeing. Governments are self serving and people need to take care of themselves.

Why do you need an expert for this? Would a certain professor make people answer questions differently or something? I don't see this as a good reason to be skeptical of the results. This is how all studies/surveys for the news are done.

Its no wonder there's little trust in the government with what's going on here. There shouldn't be this much divide when it comes to the trustworthiness of the federal and local governments. They all need to work together if they want to get through their many crises. What's the saying? A divided house can't stand?

This is the kind of behavior we expect from Putin's Russia. And we can expect more and more of these land grabs as time goes on. Just look at what's happening now. Russia's back at it again. Today it's Ukraine. Tomorrow who will it be? And the day after that ...
I don't blame the citizens for not trusting their government. What a mess. I hope for a peaceful resolution soon.

Armenia's choice to stay silent on Russia's invasion of Ukraine to keep their economic ties in tact with the country is a small factor for Russian politics. What would really change the balance is a unified push from the UN against Russia. We need the UN member nations to take a unified stand against Russian aggression in Ukraine.

Stating Armenia simply refuses to take a stance on the Russian invasion of Ukraine is because of their economic dependence on Russia may not be entirely true. It may be a bit premature to say that. Perhaps Armenia simply doesn't have an opinion on the invasion. Perhaps they for support simply don't want the backlash of the rest of the International Community. Perhaps Armenia doesn't feel they need to make a statement since everyone should know where they stand. Do you think Armenia can afford to lose russia, can they afford to keep them?

The world is not as black and white as the media portrays. This applies to war more than anything. On top of that the Russia/Ukraine war is more murky than the average war. Soft baiting Armenia to take a side(the right side) is stupid. The powers that be simply want to drum up support for Ukraine here and are softly berating anyone not taking part. It makes zero sense from any angle for Armenia to take a side here.

The article should probably be taken at face value.  Its arguments are basing a broad conclusion on a small or unrepresentative sample.  The article doesn't provide concrete examples of evidence of how the general population of Armenia feels about the war.  If they want to add weight to their arguments better evidence such as interviews or scientifically based opinion polls would help.

I don't think there is a clear answer to this dilemma. Armenia seems very intertwined with Russia both for economic reasons and security reasons. Is there a way for Armenia to continue to benefit from Russia but not support them in ways that cause harm to other nations? If they have to break ties with Russia they are likely to suffer economically but continuing to support Russia may result in negative consequences with other nations. Maybe there is a way for Armenia to maintain relationships with Russia and other nations that they will benefit from.

This article really tries to ignore the historic, fraternal relations between the peoples of Armenia and Russia. They have been allies traditionally for centuries. That relationship has weathered a lot of outside interference, like the people in this article are trying to push, and has proven mutually beneficial. I hope this war that has no direct connection to Armenia doesn't force its government to abandon that tradition.

We can't form an opinion of one country based on the opinions of a few citizens. If we do this we can make huge errors in judgement, leading to further problems. What if we make trade or economic decisions that are miscalculated? This could lead to mistrust or even war. Global trade or the global economy could collapse.

Well, either Armenia publicly condemns Russia, which would mean making a powerful enemy, or they remain neutral and have other countries hate them for it. Its a lose-lose. Why do what everyone else is doing and take a side? They get nothing out of it.

What else is the country supposed to do? Either they stay completely silent and go on the way they've been going on, or they'll be the next target for Russian invaders. It's easy for us to criticize them from our comfortable positions, but we must understand that they have no real alternative.

It''s not easy being in such a delicate and precarious situation like that of Armenia. I hope they are able to find better support from Western democratic nations, but I doubt it. Unfortunately, Armenia is just the kind of country which gets lost among all the competing anxieties which perplex busy nations like the United States and those of western Europe. Let's hope for better days for Armenia, and perhaps even independence from Russia's influence.

The leaders of Armenia are being cowardly here, as are the people. They need to speak out against Russia or things with them won't change. It seems they either don't care or are to cowardly! They are obviously reliant on them, but that shouldn't be much of an excuse. Speaking out could get them in good with the rest of the world!

Well, isn't the statement of the article pretty obvious? I mean, those alternatives you provide don't really seem plausible. I mean, how can they simply have no opinion on the matter? On the other hand, the economy is a real and significant thing and that sort of rationale makes sense.
The government is in the position to supply all with easy access to the internet. To prohibit that is a violation of their authority.

Their government has got to be hiding something nefarious if they think its worth going through all this trouble. Maybe they are actively committing genocide on their people or something. Why else censor everything? Bottom line is that censoring the internet is to hide what they are doing to their people and prevent them from speaking out.

I think that we need to focus on the worst countries first, such as Syria and North Korea. I think that the only way to address the issue of freedom is to tackle the worst instances first. Turkmenistan may be low on the list of freedom in the world, but we need to systematically address countries at the bottom of the list first, to solve this issue.

Those countries are too far gone. I think Turkmenistan is a more reasonable one to start with in terms of bringing attention to it at least. Most people already know about Syria and NK. Not many know about Turkmenistan. This study should hopefully bring more attention to what the people there go through.

It's only natural for a country with a history such as theirs would try to limit internet access with censorship.  They won't let their people be free, no matter how much attention is brought to this problem.  The internet is about freedom personified so trying to control it is futile.

Turkmenistan is censoring the internet and slowing the internet down for its citizens. Who is going to be the next country to do this? And how long before it reaches us here in the United states? If it happens in the united states, it could happen in any country in the west.
It's natural for people here to seek freedom. Turkmenistan isn't offering that. Censorship and full control is all their leaders impose.

Their government is treating them like cattle. Its a totally unnatural way to live for humans. We want and need to talk to people and find information whenever we want it. Its natural to be social and curious. Humans are social creatures, this is what all biologists say! Keeping us from talking to others is like keeping us in a zoo.

Turkmenistan's internet censorship is no different from that of other authoritative state. The reality seems like this is something that has to be tolerated, since it either that or go without access. But, isn't censoring internet and stifling freedom of expression like living without access?
