Wouldn't it be better to fight for relaxed rules rather than accepting extreme censorship or no access, as if those are the only choices?

While Turkmenistan censoring the internet is wrong and should be stopped immediately for many valid reasons, I don't think it's likely at all that it will start happening in the west. Western governments tend to have checks and balances that prevent them from crossing certain lines that detract from citizens freedoms. Turkmenistan is one of the least free countries in the world. We should always be vigilant and protect our freedoms as  much as possible, but we don't need to cause an undue amount of concern either. That level of balance is important so we do not go too far or become too complacent. It is true as well that we must not be complacent in allowing Turkmenistan to censor its people, we must stand up to this bully and encourage them to open up their internet. It will be a good first step. #Freedom4Turkmenistan

I think you're jumping to conclusions. Turkmenistan isn't blocking the internet because it is committing genocide, as far as anyone knows. It's just that they are an authoritarian government, and like all authoritarian governments, they can only remain in power through suppression of its citizens, by controlling them economically and through propaganda. A free internet is a threat to their existence, which is why they block so much of it.

Turkmenistan has the slowest internet in the world. They are only ahead of North Korea and war-torn Syria in terms of fredom. But the good thing is that at least have access. Maybe if the people let the government know their disappointment the internet can be sped up. It's not good that their internet is slow, but I'm sure they are making improvements.
Their overall safety is more important. It is very dangerous in the middle east and this is less of an issue. Worries should be put in perspective.

Clearly, this visit was made at the wrong time. It is only natural to be suspicious of an Armenian visit to Iran on such a horrific anniversary. Suspicious will be roused in such strange timing. Armenia should have thought the visit out first. A visit at a better planned time likely would have led to less controversy.

Why are there so many Iranians focused on a war in a foreign country? I think they have enough problems at home to worry about. I guess they need a distraction from all the human rights abuses and protests that are going on.

I agree, they shouldn't worry about what's going on in a different country when stuff is happening in their own country. It's time to get rid of distractions and worry about yourself. They need to end up getting rid of their distractions and focus on what's going on there, it's time to get rid of distraction and move on.

Its only natural for Azerbaijan to be wary of Iran. If you're a secular country like them, of course you'd be suspicious of a country as religious as them. Its an us vs. them situation we see in humanity and nature all the time. If you don't believe in killing innocents and some other people do, naturally you will be suspicious of them.

I agree with you. Seems that there must be more going on then what we know about otherwise it really makes no sense that they are getting involved in yet another hot situation. I think they feel they can get involved in whatever they want due to the fact they are nuclear armed.

Something needs to be done about these tensions and loss of human rights. Everyone deserves an fair and equal education in their own language. Isn't education a human right? Don't we all want peace and unity throughout the world? We need to do what we can to ensure all people have a good education easily accessible.

There's always some kind of conflict over there in the middle east. How don't they get tired of the constant fighting? I pray for the people who just want to live peacefully. Maybe one day they will all be able to live a somewhat normal, care-free life.

We need to get away from these traditions that are causing hate and rising tensions between nations. This Azeri and Armenian conflict dates back a long time. Tradition has it that their citizens hate one another. There is no way to move forward with any sort of peace if we are stuck with a hate filled tradition. We need to challenge these traditions and not cling to them. Easier said than done, but we must have hope for a better tomorrow.

I can see why the meeting between the Azerbaijan's President Ilham Aliyev and Armenia's Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan had it's detractors. There is certainly some controversy between the two countries and some people will always hold a grudge. I think we need to go back to more traditional views on this issue. Remember how we would let the past be the past? How we would forgive and forget? That was successful in our past and it surely can be a success in our current day as well. It does not mean that the past grievances can't be addressed, it's more about looking at those problems with a more impartial view. I'm sure if we can do this that these countries will be able to form closer ties and will prosper because of it. Traditionally I would say that would be a win-win for everyone involved.

What a complicated and messy legacy of both Tsarist and Soviet Russia. Can it ever be untangled? Can justice ever reign in that region? Let's hope so. It's a worldwide issue requiring coordinated resolutions, a collective problem.

If a group of people take up a quarter of your population, you should take their opinions seriously, even if you're not a Democracy. Upsetting so many people will obviously lead to no good. The government has to do something to calm the tensions between these two groups of people. Keep the peace.
Once you get youth active in doing something they may never cease. They may do things they should take no part in. Society's road to anarchy is possibly paved.

Imagine how much better off we'd be in terms of the climate if we just embraced the natural ways humans lived before the creation of all these artificial technologies. People used to know how to live in harmony with nature. We wouldn't have to be worrying about the ocean knocking at our doors if every tiny aspect of our lives didn't involve pollution.

I agree with what they are doing, people need to step out and help out with global warming. Good things are being done with planting trees to help the environment. Even helping a little makes a different and it's not that hard to plant a tree. We end up appreciated even the little bit that people do for the environment.

I think we have bigger problems to deal with that our youth being active in causes they believe in. It seems like you want them to be quiet and just go along with whatever you tell them to. Yet, you probably are also in the crowd that screams that the youth are lazy. Perhaps the youth will go on to do a far better job that you could when it comes to addressing issues like climate change, poverty and education.

If you live in one of those Caribbean areas, I assume you should be more worried about food, violence, shelter, etc, more than you should be worried about climate change. The other things have consequences right now as opposed to the future with climate change. Most of the climate change-related stuff is just predictions!

It is great to see so many younger kids taking initiative to do what the older generation does not want to deal with. Hopefully this will make the world much safer for those yet to come. The future will be in the best of hands.

Making decisions on climate policy because some KIDS think its best is insane. Adults run the country. They know what to do as they have the experience. Kids are kids and don't know what they're even protesting. There's a reason we don't let kids be politicians.

Mia Mottley says she expects people to be refugees if the climate crisis isn't solved. Because she thinks that the islands are vulnerable. This is very concerning. Which island will survive this? Will any of them? This may even reach further than just the caribbean.

I see you are using the dubious words of the infamous Dr Fred Smith. I never knew he was such an expert in what it means to let the youth be passionate about something and start a movement. I wonder what kind of movements he got into in order to end up like he is today. Instead of giving him a platform to spew his ignorance, we need to listen to the people who are actual experts in the field. The ones that are an the ground at these events trying to save our planet. Including the youth that you don't want to get into any movements.

Extremely impressive youth movement going on in the Caribbean, they are the future and are poised to protect the planet. Everyone on the planet needs to come forward and support what these young people are doing. I think in the present day we have lost a key cog between the generations, we have created too large of a gap for many to cross. That is a real shame and it must be addressed, we need to be able to communicate with our youth like we did in the past. Though many are on the right path, there are some that could use the guidance of those with more experience. That would be a great thing and can surely lead to more understanding for all involved of how to tackle this huge problem that is being faced by our earth. As much of a challenge as it will be, together all of us can overcome it and make all of our previous generations proud.

It is certainly inspiring to see this kind of innovation and commitment to causes people find important. Let's join voices with the hopeful and the young. Can you imagine the difference it would make if nearly everyone planted a tree? That's nearly 8 billion trees!

Adults got us into this mess. Not kids. Maybe just because someone is an "adult" does not make them magically have the best ideas. Just because someone young or old has an idea does not make the idea more or less functional. These kids are out there trying to make a difference by simply planting some trees like Tristan Morgan is. I am pretty sure that is a task that any age group would be capable of to try to help combat climate change. I am sure that more trees is not going to hurt anything. Not become one with mother nature is no way to go in the world. Everyone should be for nature and keeping the environment great. Lets protect what we have in this world as nature intended.

It is clear what the people want here. The governments must take action to support their people and promote conservation for the environment. Experts have given many insights, it is now up to the government to listen, the earth needs help now!

I feel that there is a need for climate protests yes but not everyone can be on board with it or on the time table that the protestors want. The picture is bigger than the issues they have made the centerpiece of their argument. That being said, most people do not have the time or ability to protest for changes no matter how much they want it or agree with it. In fact, most people believe that climate change is real and happening. The masses want change without a doubt and there are individuals fighting for climate change but support for the cause is limited because people have real lives they are trying to lead, no matter how much they believe in the issue.

I think the majority of people are getting on board with climate action.  Everyone is seeing the changes as they happen.  Even older folks, the most anti-climate group are seeing this and starting to think they should support it.  They are the ones that remember when it was colder.  For example my state is very conservative but even older people know that is not snowing anymore like it was when they were kids.  I think that it the key and the younger people are leading the way with this.
It is great to see the youth getting involved. They are brave to stand up for what they believe in.

Humans are meant to live in harmony with nature. It is not natural for us to be scared of the environment and its effects on us. These young people deserve a lot of praise for what they're doing! What we are doing to the environment is not natural!

This is great to see so much support for the environment. It is necessary that we protect our environment, why wouldn't we want to? Everyone needs the environment to survive. The environment cannot be replaced once it is destroyed. We need to take action now before irreperable damage is done.

I think that we can all learn from our youth. We see them going out and standing up for their beliefs, especially when it comes to climate change. It is going to cause them more issues as they grow up in the world with the climate situation worsening. Let's get behind them and applaud them.

Most people in the world want positive action to combat climate change - 79% to be exact as surveys have shown. There is a cry for robust action on this issue from the collective voice. Such an overwhelming consensus signifies the magnitude and urgency we are facing. It's just too big and widespread to ignore anymore. Because of this, we must act to ensure the future of the planet is a good one for humanity. With so many united in this belief, doesn't this prove that imminent action is a necessity for preserving the world for future generations?

I am one of those people who want to see immediate action on the issue of climate change, it is a very serious problem that will effect the whole world. That being said, I want this done because it is a real problem, not because so many people are in agreement with me. Your argument seems to be mostly based on the fact that most people are worried about climate change, that is probably true but it shouldn't be such a focus. The focus should be on the core issue, the planet is in trouble and we must help prevent any more damage. We must make people understand that this is important and must be done quickly if we are to make a true difference. Like those young people who protested around the world, they are seeing the problem and trying to fix it. Can we work together and find a solution here to get more action and less words?

Either the governments listen to the people and enact policies that will help with climate change, or we all ignore the issues and then die. We can't wait any longer. The young people need to be listened to or everyone will suffer.

The majority of the people who were in the protests were young people, but I think that most people would agree that large corporations and governments need to consider the environmental impacts of their actions. It's not getting better quickly. We all need this planet. So let's take care of it. And they're just not moving quickly.

We should also still be concerned with creating more jobs in the area of Berrima. The Korean company would have brought a lot more economic support to the area. But it's important to note that the area needs to stay clean and livable for the people and the animals. Where will New South Wales be in 20 years if we do not concern ourselves with the environmental impact of our decisions today. New South Wales is a big part of Australia and in Australia is a large part of the Pacific area which is in need of Environmental warriors.

There is too much emotional pleasing in this article simply because most people allegedly believe in it. This isn't even true butt the article tries to frame it that way in a soft manner. Ot tries to act as though the majority are for it but this is merely the case at best with the tiny minority of people involved. This is a problem with all special interests. The average person doesn't care enough to be this involved.

Caving in because a few has-been celebs oppose a coal mine is a dumb move. I guess we're going to roll over for every celebrity cause and sink the whole economy. Decisions like this one need to be made by experts who understand the real impact. Losing all those local jobs won't hurt Nicole Kidman and Leo Sayer, but it sure hurts a lot of Joe and Jane Does and small business owners who are struggling to recover from the impact of covid.

I do wonder if it would have been approved had celebs not been upset about it. If Kidman's and other rich peoples' houses hadn't been affected and it was all just normal peoples' homes, I bet it would have been approved. Does anyone else think celebs have too much sway in politics?

I am happy, the environment is being protected against this mine. I do think we need to look at other ways to boost the local economy. It is also important the government look into regulations for further development plans that protect the environment. Ecologist, Dr. Seema said, mining not only harms the environment but also impedes sustainable economic growth. There needs to be a balance that benefits both the environment and the economy. I think we need to get more information about impacts before we move forward with any regulations. Are there other experts that have different opinions? We need to stick to the facts in order to gain the most benefit possible. How else can we benefit the economy if the mine is not a good option?

This whole push for environmentalism is going too far. A coal company that would have created hundreds of jobs and brought all the benefits associated was stopped, for what? Because some people are worried about global climate change? What's next, even the 'renewable' energy sources are bad and we all just have to live incredibly basic lives with no luxuries, all for the sake of the environment? Are hundreds of lost jobs going to turn into thousands, or even millions? We need to find a balance.
It is obvious the environmental impacts were most important here. We cannot argue that anything else is more important. Can anyone tell me anything that matters more?

This is very true. That's because most normal people have much bigger concerns than things like this. Hard to be worried about something like the relatively minuscule effects of one little coal plant when you are struggling to get by, paycheck to paycheck. The government should be focused on the more important things.

I think it's great that the coal mine was blocked. We need to keep moving towards more clean and sustainable sources of energy, that don't damage and pollute communities, and harm wildlife and the environment. Countless studies have demonstrated that clean and renewable energy sources benefit the environment and improve the health conditions of communities in their vicinity.

I agree that basing the decision around the opinions of just celebrities is really not the best way to make choices. However, I am not sure that we should be relying on just experts either. What we need is a balanced view of such issues that include the opinions of all people. That would include regular people, experts, celebrities and so on. Regular people can be great for getting a view from ground level, experts can help educate all of us on the finer details. The celebrities can bring a lot of attention to the subject. Aren't all of these people very important to solve problems?

So they listened to celebrities and locals who have no real understanding of climate change or the coal industry? The people who work on this project know what's best and would have provided many people jobs! The benefits to not building it aren't even known, but as the people in charge of the project said, the benefits to building it would have meant 300 families with jobs.

I'm sure for a lot of other people, the economic benefits would have been more important. Just because they lost doesn't mean other things don't matter, or that other people with other interests weren't truly right. We have to take a balanced approach and consider everyone's positions.

Does anyone care about the coal miners? This is taking away the jobs from people and their families. There are a lot of honest hardworking people who are just trying to support their loved ones. It is important to have transition plans, retraining programs, or other employment opportunities for these people. I saw no mention of this. Though I know that transitioning away from coal is important, we should not be so hasty.

Is this really helpful? I mean coal mines have always been a source of income for the local economy. For years they have provided jobs and supported the economy. Aren't we just creating a new problem by stopping them?

Since that is the case and everyone knew that the outcome would be something of this nature, its on everyone involved to have started a transition plan. There are other jobs out there and the government should have stepped in to offer miners who wanted to transition to other jobs free training in those fields and the opportunity to gain employment. Miner themselves also needed to start to plan for this future. It's not like it came out of nowhere. They are hardworking people and with the help of the government will land on their feet.

Dumping pollution into rivers and having the entire sky over every major city filled with toxic fumes also provided jobs and supported the economy for years. It being that way isn't a strong argument for it to continue being that way. You're right that problems will emerge as a result, but it's people's right to prioritize the climate in this specific area and try to alleviate the lost jobs and economic harm in other ways.

Most people will agree that while being more responsible for our actions that affect the environment is important, so is the fact that people should be able to provide for their families. Jobs are important as well.
I think this is a shame. So many jobs were lost because we continue to listen to the bias opinions of activists who are guided by politics. Hopefully other establishments don't follow these actions.

Both things can be done at once. Too often, concerns about jobs and how workers in these sorts of industries will be negatively affected are used to push back against protecting the environment. There should be more focus on talking about how to create whatever combination of job training, welfare, and other such transition programs to help these people while we make the necessary changes, like stopping new coal plants.
There are two issues here. Coal is not the real issue, but control of the people. They want to frustrate the coal communities and the electoral inclinations they have.
This is getting out of control! This will keep people out of new jobs just to make a measly difference in the global temperature!

I'm happy with the court's decision. Ripping up the Earth to grab its coal is outdated and not good for nature in general. The long-term consequences cannot be positive. There are a number of ways to harness the power of nature (wind, solar) without harming it, and I look forward to the day when that is the norm. If it takes the courts to lead Australia into the future, so be it.

It seems like most of the people in Australia are on board with the phasing out of coal as an energy source. I think this has been the prevailing attitude across a big part of the world as well. It does not surprise me that the courts are starting to see the science behind the reliance on fossil fuels to further our industriousness. Most scientists agree that renewables are better for the environment than coal burning plants are. Time marches on as does innovation. The radio gave way to Television and newspapers to the internet. These are things that people all have adapted to and accepted for the most part. Coal mining and oil drilling are going that same route. Most people would agree that losing a few thousand coal mining jobs in an effort to leave a livable planet for our children and grandchildren is a worthy sacrifice. There are many other mining jobs that these coal miners could transition to and not have to learn any kind of "new" line of work.

All females should have the right to legal abortion if it falls within the guidelines of their countries laws. The rules need to be made more clear so that doctors and hospitals do not run the risk of getting in trouble for doing the procedure. Clear laws on the matter will make things easier on everyone. Many experts will tell you the same, that clear and concise laws will make the process easier.

It seems clear that abortion is a medical development, an innovation of human beings. It's not something you find among any other animal groups. And why not? Because it's not natural. Surely this means that it can't really be right. You can't go so directly against nature and think what you're doing is right. Cases like this one are sad, but nature has always been red in tooth and claw.

It's wild to me that the religious groups are doing what they're doing here. They actually pursued charges against the doctors. How about focusing on the person who raped a preteen? Apparently we don't just need to protect women's right to abortions, but girls' rights as well in some places.

A child should not have to carry out a pregnancy, and certainly one that was caused by rape. If the government wants to be so against abortion then they need to start protecting girls from rape and making the consequences of rape very harsh. The government also needs to form a society in which women are cared for and supported after such a terrible event.

If the government of Argentina grants the right to an abortion for women and girls who are assaulted, there will be unintended consequences. One right granted will only trigger the demand for another right, and another, and so on, like a kid in a candy shop, and soon they will have countrywide abortions on demand and a plummeting birth rate. Be careful lawmakers of Argentina!

It's a shame that this is still something up for debate in so many places. Even if you don't want abortions to happen, all the evidence and experts show that restricting access doesn't really reduce abortions. It just increases how many people get hurt. That story is awful, but its something that probably happens extremely rarely. This doesn't mean the authorities are wrong or immoral when it comes to this issue. They know what is best for their people and society. If its the law now, its the law. Religious leaders might not be doctors, but they know what's best when it comes to aboriton as that is a moral and spiritual matter.
This is insane! Will they have post-birth abortions next? Abortion should be outlawed in any circumstance.

The state of abortion access in these areas is terrible and this article highlights why well. How is asking to save a woman's life insane? Is it reasonable to ask a woman to carry a pregnancy resulting from rape to term? Causing her further trauma? Someone else's religion or beliefs should not affect another person's life, future and health. We need to focus on empathy and compassion. Most people agree that abortion should be legal,  so I don't see why Argentina has this problem.  The majority's voice should be the guiding light for lawmakers.  That's what democracy is about.  In this case, the majority believe that abortion should be legal.   This should be simple.  Give the people what they want,  give women what they want.

Is one guy getting arrested that big a deal? Especially in a country like Azerbaijan, where there are much bigger problems. How about all the ethnic minorities in the country who are constantly being attacked in ways much worse than an arrest? Maybe things like that should be the priority.

I truly hope that Mr. Aslan is released soon; this is a very discouraging news story but not really that surprising.  we live in a world where human compassion is severely lacking.  It makes me very sad that events like these continue to take place.  More work needs to be done to make this a safer world.
I think this is terrible. Once we start silencing people who disagree with us, where does it end? Do we then try to control any form of criticism?

I think this article is jumping to conclusions for too fast. The details of what led to the arrests are really glossed over here. Agree with your comment. If they will start here with one person, then what is next? Arresting everyone that they don't approve of?

I would think the government of Azerbaijan has more important issues than arresting a civil rights journalist who had not been in the country for awhile. All they have done is create even bigger issues over one that did not exist to begin with. They really need to get their act together.

It is a big deal to his family! It is not okay for the government to go around kidnapping people off the streets and then avoiding to answer questions. My thoughts are with his family and friends at this time.

Azerbaijan has a long way to go before the people can enjoy the same freedoms I enjoy every day without thinking about it. Let's all hope for a more free and just Azerbaijan.

This is how it starts. First they will say they just want equal rights, then they will want special privileges such as taxpayer funded surgeries and being able to go to any bathroom they want. Then they will demand you be attracted to them as well!

Is this a government unilaterally denying them the laws that the majority support, or do the people not actually support it? I don't believe it's fair to have minorities pushing through legislation and changes that go against the will of the people so this is what I want to read more about.

If they continue to take the rights of transgender people, what's to stop them from taking the rights of others? Women? Religious minorities? Racial minorities? Where will it stop? We need to consider long term impacts. Stop further targeting. We need to stand up for all rights.

The fact that they already have laws in place to protect trans people and they have high profile parades where they aren't afraid to march proves that wrong, though. I'm very surprised actually. If they are this progressive with trans people, why not gays?

I mean, this is good news I guess, but is it really that important? Especially in a place like Pakistan, with all the serious problems they have. Maybe they should be more focused on the abject poverty and commonplace violence that huge swaths of their population have instead of some tiny minority.
The people can be patient or protest. These changes take time. A conservative place like Pakistan won't just cave in to all trans issues at once.

They are already making progress, much more so than other countries are. Why try to push harder which will just lead to animosity and will end up being counterproductive? Either take what progress you're getting now and continue on this pace, or push harder and risk losing it all. The balance approach of just going at the current pace will yield the best results and result in fewer enemies.

While the news might only apply to a minority of people, the big important thing here is that it at least brings awareness to an issue that should have more attention. Liberty for all should be a focus that society needs to work toward all around the world and that makes this issue into a worldwide issue. It is only through collective effort that can bring about change; and it's not just about those being directly affected, but also about maintaining balance, equity, and fairness in our society. Standing for liberty should be everyone's goal.

Irrespective of one's personal view, the idea of harming, and certainly of killing, anyone over such an issue is abhorrent. The statistics in this article are extremely alarming. This must stop. Let's hope it does, and as soon as possible.

It doesn't really matter much what the majority thinks, although it would be nice if the majority was accepting of trans individuals. The Transgendered Persons act has passed, and is a matter of law regardless of what the majority think. It just hasn't been implemented. Anyway, I wonder if the majority would be accepting of all the violence (sometimes lethal) that trans individuals have to face. That said, the media blackout of the event is unfortunate because that might have helped ease social prejudices, which is where real concrete change will occur. Exposure to different viewpoints is how tolerance is fostered. Meanwhile, implementing the law will save lives, whether the majority realizes it or not.

While that's true, that doesn't mean they have to sit back silently and wait for things to happen without their input. They are just trying to get what they deserve, as fast as possible. Even if protests like this only slightly increase the rates at which they get what they want, that's still better than nothing. Any progress, however slow, restores some faith and brings hope for a better future.
This is the perfect example of someone using their fame for good. he is singing about what he believes in and therefore can make change with art.

Why do we take the word and opinions of artists so seriously? If people keep listening to them and basing their opinions off theirs, none of us will have our own way of thinking. Plus, they are all rich and the rich don't have our interests in mind. Why rely on what this one guy says?

Why should we listen to this musician?  What does he know about how a country should be run?  I understand having sympathy for those who are abused and neglected and am not belittling it, but let the real experts handle it. Let's leave these delicate topics to policy makers who invest their lives working on these issues.

When you combine the numbers of women and children, they outnumber the men and adults so their needs and rights need to be met. The fact that the country is so poor in this aspect that a singer has to bring attention to it is sad! Their needs hold much more weight, especially since they have been neglected for so long!

I completely agree that many celebs don't have fully accurate information. Think about their influence they have in being a positive force for change. Dr. Mary Monroe, a well known psychologist and speaker, had a lecture on this topic not too long ago and said that even if a celeb doesn't have all the information, their words will cause someone to want to have that information. Of course, it's important to bring unbiased information that is accurate, but even if starting the conversation could lead that "one person" who could bring change, wouldn't that be worth it? The ripple effect that starts from a single stone is always massive, don't you think?

We should listen to artists like this man.  Artists throughout history have made it a habit to bring attention to social causes.  It has a long history and tradition that I am glad to see still in place.  Artists like Picasso made art that spurred societal change.  Let's continue to allow this and embrace it.

Yeah, its a shame more celebs don't use their fame for anything other than enriching themselves. I wonder if this guy will actually make his country enact any significant changes. I hope so. If he brings enough attention to injustice, those people who love him can vote to make a difference. He'd be a hero.

Music has always been a vehicle for change. For long before recorded history, all arts were a means for people to express what they think of the world they live in and the world they'd like to live in. It's unfortunate that so many governments are trying so hard to kill that tradition.

I totally agree, real world change is what we need! Music and art have their place, but changing the world? It really don't make the change that everyone thinks it does. Isn't art more for personal enjoyment, anyway? It might give a handful of people a new thought process, but those same people are likely the internet activists that are going to just change their profile picture to a black box to join a online crusade. It's not helping. It's true real world change that is going to make a difference, not a catchy viral song.

Great story about Elias Atayi and his dedication to making music to amplify human rights. I think it's a great idea and I'm certain that there are vast amounts of people who agree to me. I mean, think about it, who is against human rights? I have never heard anyone come out against them, so that has to mean it's nearly universal in support! Just having that sort of backing shows that defending human rights is the correct thing to do, we all need to step up and spread this message far and wide. With how many people are behind this it is sure to be a success! #HumanRights

I agree that music has been important for many cultural changes through history. I am thinking of how protest music like "We Shall Overcome" emboldened the Civil Rights movement in the USA. Authorities fear musicians like Elias Atayi because they provide inspiration and boost morale to important causes that threaten the status quo.

This man should be an example to all.  He is trying to change things in his country by using his visibility as an artist to champion women's and children's rights.  Hopefully, he will inspire others in his county to go in the same direction in his country, Togo. Elias Atayi is not just an artist, but a catalyst for change.

No one wants to lose someone to something that should be a celebration. There are much better ways to celebrate.  Let's learn from these tragedies. We can have wonderful parties without guns and possible tragedy. All parties should be gun free.

You can't tell people how to celebrate.  Just because some people are too stupid and irresponsible to fire guns doesn't mean this right should be taken away from everyone. It  will spiral out of control.  It might get so out of hand, one can't even burn leaves in their front yard lest they burn down everyone's property.
The rate of death from celebratory gunfire is so low that little attention should be done. There are much worse things going on in the country. Poverty and homelessness are bigger issues.

Celebratory gunfire has been a part of different cultures for decades if not hundreds of years. Trying to stop it now because of a few accidents is silly. Are we going to stop driving due to thousands being killed in wrecks every year Tradition is important. All cultures have them!

I have to disagree. As the popular saying goes, guns don't kill people - people kill people. Gun owners, by and large, are responsible citizens, a fact that no one can really argue. The majority of gun owners are law-abiding citizens who are just as concerned about safety, if not moreso, than non gun owners. Statistics about violent crime bear this out, since most gun owners have clean records. That's why the second amendment is so widely supported.

The grassroots efforts will eliminate celebratory gunfire one hundred percent. This type of effort is the most effective way to address the gun violence issue. Listening to concerned citizens is the only way to end this type of gun violence. This may not always be the case, but this issue is a perfect usage of grassroots organization.

And for many more thousands of years before that, guns never even existed. Maybe they should stick to the more natural traditions. Surely we can be happy celebrating in more natural ways, ones that don't involve metal inventions that can maim and kill people from miles away.

People that have guns need to be more careful with them, they aren't toys. You can celebrate in different ways without shooting the gun into the air. Hearing about a 10 year old girl that got killed by a random bullet is senseless and needs to be stopped, this is heartbreaking. People need to be held accountable for their actions.

While it is dangerous to shoot guns in the air. This has been done for a long time and is tradition. They can make some changes in sensitizing people about safety, but still preserve the tradition, to avoid needless deaths.

I had no idea this was a problem. I've seen it in movies, even in cartoons, but I didn't know such numbers could even be possible. I'm glad there are people working on this problem. Stricter laws and better enforcement seem like a good place to start.
How can anybody be this stupid? Randomly shooting in celebration will lead to deaths from stray bullets. I'm glad they are doing something about this!

Actually, where I'm at, it is illegal to burn leaves in your yard. There IS a fire risk, just like there's a risk of death due to celebratory shooting, and I'm fine with measures to reduce those risks. You're trying to make a slippery-slope argument, as if someone's going to take away all guns. But we can take safety measures and still keep our civil liberties. Los Angeles warns of criminal charges with jail time to deter the practice, so it's possible to respect responsible gun ownership and curb reckless behavior.
These are a serious matter and must be treated as such. The government must be transparent.
First they start with fake threats. Later they detonate real bombs. These countries have always had problems with such things.
The false bomb threats are a problem but not as bad as other problems that exist. Global warming will end us all. If left unchecked we might not have a world to live in.

I have to disagree. The threats are a huge problem, they are keeping people from going about their daily lives in all aspects. It is affecting the security of their government, the mental health of all citizens. This is a very serious problem in need of a solution.

I believe that your comment may be misguided. While you think that fake threats always lead to actual violence that is not always the case. Just because you believe in the past this has always been the case, doesn't mean this will be true for all time.  Cannot you recall other instances from the past where different actions were chosen then which would not be now? People do change and so do their actions and I'm sure with enough thought you would see that as well.

I'm sorry to hear about the chaos and confusion aroused by these false alerts. However, there is outright war going on, with Russian aggression exerting itself against Ukraine. All threats are threatening, of course, but some pale in comparison to others, especially those which involve rockets being fired into your buildings and killing hundreds or thousands of people. Kosovo is right to consider the potential connections there, but it might also want to reconsider its decision not to place sanctions on Russia, since the ongoing war is a much more severe situation than mere false alerts, and things might get much worse as Russia gets the upper hand in its conflict with Ukraine and then Kosovo may have more to face than scary phone calls and false alerts.
They can call a bluff on the threats. Or they can take precautions. Either way they choose to handle it, there will be risks to deal with.

The fact that the authorities haven't provided an explanation is suspect. This makes me think they either have something to do with it or are hiding something big. Why else would they not inform the people? If they have nothing to hide, come clean about who is responsible!

It seems like these sorts of conflicts are just eternal. Tribalism just seems too innate and natural in people for it to ever truly be defeated. Peaceful coexistence really seems like the rare exception to the rule, when you look at human history as a whole.

Over generalizing a situation can lead to conclusions that are a bit off mark. Letting go of a situation and giving up on finding solutions is an easy way out. Action must take place, and effort to rectify situations should be always done.

It's hard to imagine security forces having to deal with over 70 bomb threats in one day. They must have been so strained for resources! This is a prime example of the complexities of today's world, where technology can be used to spread panic and disorder in an otherwise peaceful society. I take solace in the hope that Kosovo's security forces can guide them through this difficult time.

These threats are so horrific, even if no real bombs were present.  This kind of thing makes people scared all the time.  Being in constant fear is no way to live, and these people deserve better.  Hopefully, the people responsible will be held accountable at some point.  I hope the innocent citizens can feel safe again soon.
The violence done against other is relentless between these factions. There seems to be no limits on who they can attack. Nations should unite for peace.

They really need to take care of this problem. Today, journalists are targeted. Tomorrow, academics. The next day, doctors. Sooner or later, everyone becomes a target and not a single person will be left alive.

I find it incredible that this nation cannot come together after years and years of occupation and infighting, all in the name of religion. I find it very hard to understand why people who profess to be of the same religion cannot get along in any real way. There is a real need for unity in this situation - in the natural world, all things tend to live in harmony and peace and it should be this way in religious communities as well. After all you are the SAME religion with various practices within the sects. Think of the animal kingdom and various species that live in groups and they do not have the issues humans have - we are a part of that same animal kingdom so why can't we do the same, especially amongst those who base their participation in human life on religion? Humans need to learn how to live together, in spite of and because of our individual differences.

You can't really believe the Taliban didn't have a hand in this. Tucker Carlson had a whole segment about it on Fox News where he explained the motive behind the Taliban's surprising condemnation of attacks. He insistes they just want to lull us into complacency. There's so much at stake here, including the future of US/Taliban relations. I guess I need to explore this further; Tucker's been wrong before, so it's actually important to seek out more diverse and expert opinions.

Funny how journalists, a group of professionals, equate themselves with an entire group in terms of victimhood. Not surprising some journalist would write such an idea in an article. Maybe there shouldn't be so much focus on these journalists, and a lot more on the millions of Shia Muslims who are at risk. It cheapens their plight to lump them in with journalists, like all their enemies hate both equally.
It is in the nature of terrorists to try and take out the brightest. And those who expose them. It should also be our ideal to thwart this nature and let human nature's kindness reign.

You mention religion, and I think religious difference is the root of the problem. But I'm less optimistic about these groups finding any unity in their faith and thus a way to live in harmony. All religions are like this -- they serve to divide by magnifying differences instead of finding points of commonality. Historically, there have been attempts to bring these groups together, and it always falls apart on the basis of religion. Unfortunately, that means there is no path to religious harmony in this or any region of the world.

That's very true, we need to stand united against this threat. If the whole world doesn't come together to do something about this, in the most concrete, direct manner, it will only spiral out of control and result in far more death and destruction. Either we work together and solve all this immediately or let chaos reign. There's no real alternative.

When you look at these terrible situation, it is important to keep in mind the long tradition of violence between the Sunni and Shia Muslims. Hopefully they can move past their differences. Remember, different Christian groups such as the Catholics and Protestants have managed to peacefully coexist despite having a difficult history with each other. Hopefully adopted a similar pathway of reconciliation will be possible.

The biggest issue that the middle east has faced is corrupt and power hungry leaders for generations.   Leaders in the area use religion as a shield to protect them and justify their horrific acts.  Until they sperate religion and politics, these events will continue to plague these countries.  Shia Islam is the 2nd biggest branch of the religion.  However, that doesn't mean that they should make decisions for the country because of that.   God does not want his children to fight no matter the faith.
It is educational to learn that the Taliban condemned these attacks along with the Arg. I didn't realize how deep the Shiite/Sunni divide really goes in terms of violent antipathy within Afghanistan.

If the majority of journalists feel threatened by this and speak out, it would be a good thing.  They do have a voice, even though terrorists are attempting to silence them as well.  Listen to these men and women.  Hopefully, their words will make a difference.  A collective voice has the power to shift perspectives and push for change.
At the end of the day we are all human. I am glad it ended somewhat peacefully and no one was injured.
There is a conflict of tradition and progressiveness. The people have to be on either side. Not everyone will be on board with the pride parades, and that's fine.

So sad that people are still getting attacked just for having different beliefs. It is our differences that make us stronger together, and the violence demonstrated goes against basic survival instincts we witness everyday within nature. You naturally see different species interact everyday helping each other in their survival journey. Instead of destroying each other we should take cues from natures harmony and not resort to means that threaten our own survival. It is essential we remember that our evolution has been about fostering connections, not creating barriers.

I think most people would agree everyone deserves equal rights to believe what they believe. We need to support equality. This is not just about being fair, it is about individual rights. I think most people agree that is an ideal we all strive for.

If the police are on the counter-protesters side, as the article claims, as well as the government, that doesn't bode well. I feel like this suggests most of the country are behind them as well. I hope the activists will one day be able to convince the people that their religious homophobia just has no place in modern society.

I think that they should make up their mind weather then need to be on the side of tradition or progressiveness.  I really don't think there is any other way.  They need to make a hard choice and stick with it.

Norms are being shattered and it is upsetting to many people.  To say that marriage is only between a man and a woman in not realistic.  We can make way for new ways of doing things.  However, we can still maintain the sanctity of marriage.

Up until the past 15 years or so, pride marches were not a thing and the churches had the support of most everyone. They probably don't like the fact that things are changing and our values are going away, so they are fighting for their beliefs! Society was much better, safer, and more kind before our traditional values were being threatened.

It wasn't really a good idea to call off the march because of the violent protesters.  Allowing intimidation to dictate whether others can show their disapproval of suppression of human rights, sets a dangerous precedent. Imagine if violent protestors decided men should no longer be allowed to drive because statistics show they are responsible for most accidents. Those that disapprove of such a restriction, would not be able to protest against it which may signal to officials most citizens approve of it.

Leaving the decision to end the protest on the government might be the better thing. They are the authority to do so, so let them make the call. They should take immediate steps to enforce a stricter control on these hate groups.

LGBT people in Georgia may be unable to have their parades without the irritation of "counter-protesters," which isn't great, but in places throughout the Middle East and parts of Africa and Asia, being part of LGBT will literally get you killed - stoned, buried alive, burned alive, etc. The concerns of this group in Georgia shouldn't be overestimated. The world, and that includes people who are LGBT, has bigger problems.

It's understandable that the gay community want to be treated equally, but why make such public shows of it?  It would be better if they tried to get things done quietly behind the scenes without making a fuss. In addition, they would probably have people cooperate more which would yield better results.  The old traditional way of handling things is often best.

If bloggers and social media influencers are allowed to incite violence against one group of people for whatever reason it is only a matter of time before another group is targeted for another reason. Nobody is safe if law enforcement and decent citizens and the government look the other way at violence against any group. There needs to be strict regulations against hate speech of any kind.

The struggles of the LGBTQ+ community are so heartbreaking and it seems they never catch a break in some countries. It's understandable that the people in the countries feel uneasy about breaking what is traditionally done. It can sometimes be a tightrope walk to rethink a tradition with what's right and what's traditionally wrong. If you gave LGBTQ+ more freedoms, who can say what community is next with wanting the same rights? This could end up being a snowball effect of the worst people in the world wanting rights owed to them. It could be a pathway to more uneasy changes, we should be treading lightly on these changes.

It looks like the violence in Azerbaijan culminated from a lack of the country's addressing issues against the lgbtq community. This is truly sad. Hate can often lead to violence. This may have only been a matter of time. Let other countries in the world take notice so that we can avoid these types of horrible events.

Imagine living in such a poor country and yet focusing all your attention on trans people, who make up almost 0 percent of the country. Why not focus on ending poverty or corruption or something else with actual importance? Isn't bringing prosperity and happiness to your country more important than hate?

It's clear from all polling that the vast, overwhelming majority of the population of Azerbaijan doesn't support LGBTQ rights. Does democracy not matter? The voice of the majority should be respected, even if it's contrary to the values some of us in other countries might have. It's up to us to help change that majority opinion, not force it on them.

Absolutely right! It's amazing that so many social media influencers have the power to incite violence, but lets not assume they are all eager to focus on once group and cause issue with them. We're seen so many influencers are the opposite and work to fight against injustices, many more are joining protests and and against the actions of hate groups. Of course, it's safe to say that all these influencers genuinely care about social justice and are not just doing it for the image and follows, right? We shouldn't lump them all together, okay? On the other hand, I saw an influencer last week who barely showed any interests in these issues until it started trending. It makes you wonder if they are just following trends or are they socially aware?

If people in the LGBTQ community are not protected then what is next? You cannot discriminate against one group of people and not expect that discrimination to one day be directed at you for something. People need to get out of others private lives and focus on real world problems like war and climate change.

These countries are so far behind the majority of the world. Surely they see the progress the rest of us have made with LGBT issues, yes? Shouldn't that make them think about the way they act and make them want to be like us? Its so sad. So many countries have made gay marriage legal and more over the past 10 years, and they continue to ignore that and act like this??

It's sad that people still don't realize that there's no future in discriminating against the LGBTQ community like this. All it does is hurt our communities and propagate hatred, as all evidence shows. Plus, it's even disrespectful to ourselves and our own values, to deny others such basic rights. Like Biden said, LGBTQ rights are human rights.

I think poverty and basic human rights can both be addressed. Poverty is often a sign of uneducated citizens, as is discrimination. By addressing the root causes of both issues everyone will benefit. By promoting acceptance of diversity and understanding of everyone we can help to eliminate many issues. Let's prioritize all people and everyone will benefit.

No matter the scale of global problems we're facing, this brutality is beyond comprehend. Violence is never an answer, it is saddening to know this is still happening. Their sexual orientation does not invalidate their human rights. We need to do better as a society. Also, it's high time platforms take strict action against individuals who incite such hatred and violence.

Azerbaijan needs to make radical change, right now. It's either that, or do nothing and just let the LGBTQ people in their country get completely destroyed. There is no alternative but to immediately adopt and enforce the laws that protect these people. Every single day of delay is more death and destruction.

There seems to be no doubt as to the wish of the people, who have tweeted and protested and made their will known. And the numbers don't lie. Isn't this a democracy? Doesn't a democracy thrive on the will of the people? It's time for Rajapaksa to bow to the will of the majority, which is the only right thing to do.

I'm not sure I'm really understanding this. What is the actual challenge to him holding the position? I mean, it says the opposition is arguing he doesn't have the legal right, but what is that based on? Did he not get appointed/elected to the position? What part of the law is he actually violating? Can anyone who knows more about this elaborate?

Although itâs natural to human being to want justice when you think you have been wronged in some way. Sometimes you also have to let go when itâs clear the very people that you want to lead do not in fact want you. Itâs part of our nature to fight but itâs also in our nature to reconsider balance and peace.

Unfortunately, it is the nature of politicians to squabble and vie for power like this. It's embarrassing and frustrating, yes, but it's probably the right way to govern, since this desire to acquire (and more importantly, to keep) power is innate among those who make up the political class.

What numbers are you referring to? Activists and people who tweet don't constitute democracy. The will of the people can only be represented by elections, not social media campaigns. It should say a lot that the people you're describing are the ones just telling him to quit and stop calling for elections.

Reading the facts of the article I always love when people use the law to protest or overturn something that they think is wrong in government. I do find it hasty to jump on the band wagon because the article doesnât have enough information on why the newly appointed Prime Minister is unfit. There is nothing said about his education, experience or public approval ratings just the feeling that he is unpopular among some of the people. If you look around the world nobody in office holds a 100 percent approval rate.

I'm confused. If there were two rejected no-confidence motions for him, why does the court think its okay to not allow him to be PM? Seems political to me. If you let the courts get political, you eventually get countries like Russia and Nazi Germany. Before it gets that bad, it could lead to the opposition being barred from holding office ever again, or political prisoners being taken.

I have some friends with family in the country and they tell me everything that happens involves this kind of dirty, shady corruption. They say there are no 'good guys', just a bunch of criminals on all sides working for their own interests. News like this just confirms all I've heard.

This is a very interesting political situation going on in Sri Lanka, it isn't clear who will end up being the Prime Minister in the end. It seems it will come down to the courts to decide the matter and most people think that is a good thing. I am not so sure about that, I remember the days when two disagreeing people could sit down together and work out their differences. Those days seem to be long gone now and everything must end up in a court case to be resolved. I wonder if these two in Sri Lanka might consider such an approach? It seems like a long shot, but maybe they will see the light and give it a try. It may not completely resolve the issue, but maybe it will allow them and their followers to see what they have in common. Sometimes we have to look to our past to find our future, this is exactly what should happen today in Sri Lanka.

The court doesn't seem to have a strong reason to hear the case, so I agree that the Sri Lankan court seem to be politicized. This is distressing because people will loose faith in their institutions and the government's ability to function properly. Once that happens, civil unrest and chaos will ensue. It's important to stop early signs of institutional failures before they destroy the society.

Presumably a no confidence motion isn't the only method someone might be disqualified from office. Like it says, they're not permanently stopping him from taking the role. They are just blocking it for the time being until the petition can be heard in court. That doesn't sound especially like Nazi Germany or anything. Let's wait and see how this plays out. Hopefully a fair resolution will be reached.
The government only lies and covers up. That's why media is crucial to expose things. It's why they always try to silence the free media.

It seems to me that Bangladesh must either shut down its universities or ban the internet on those campuses in order to maintain public safety for students. I don't see how students can feel safe unless immediate action is taken. Let's talk solutions, not merely options.

This kind of censorship is so unnatural. How does the government expect that students can just be made to shut up when they have such serious issues that affect them? The very nature of humans, particularly young people, is to let their voices be heard, especially in situations that really matter to them. The government here should understand that their solution is not going to solve anything.
People will naturally protest injustice. The students have every reason to. The death of their fellow student is major.

I agree completely. It's obvious that decisive action must be taken, even if viewed as extreme by some. It's either ban the internet for student safety or shut down completely. Safety comes before everything. Perhaps it's time for stricter regulation and zero-tolerance policies towards bullying. Even if it restricts some freedom, it's worth saving the lives of students.

The government really needs to respect the rights of these people. Most students are not happy with this kind of censorship. If most people aren't happy with a policy, then that should be the clearest sign that the policy is bad.
The government in these countries don't care. They will hide anything bad. They should protest as much as they like.

These kids are in college and they think its a good use of their time to harass other kids due to politics? They have tests and whatnot to worry about. Politics is for when you're older. Idiots! There are many more problems to worry about at your age. Your future, climate change, etc.

Having students protest nationwide, it's pretty clear Bangladesh issue is serious issue and needs addressing. And it's hard to ignore when the majority are echoing the same sentiment - their numbers surely can't be wrong, right? It's high time to adhere to the protesters' demands in order to bring back peace.
When you have that many people agreeing on something there is no way it can't be the right thing to do. The number of people have a lot of sway. Collective wisdom as some would say.

Any culture which tolerates "ragging" is one in which something as horrific as this can happen. There really has to be a zero tolerance policy with regard to violence. Universities are places of learning, not of barbarism. Reforms of the university system there must get underway, and as soon as possible.

That does not seem like a very reasonable reaction here. These students are the ones who will have to live with the world politics creates longer than any of the older adults who engage in politics. If anything, they should be the ones most passionate and interested in the processes that will be shaping their future. We should ensure they have a safe environment to express themselves without any fear of retribution.

Things seemed to be working well the way it is without opening pathways for refugees from other countries. This act does not seem like it would be beneficial in any way to Assam or any other part of India. The Assam Accord has been working for over 30 years.
Taking away speech from the public will only lead to more false information. People need to communicate. Keep conversations alive.

Another story about Indians not wanting any different people in their country. This whole situation just proves India is full of nationalists who are also racist. Multiculturalism will never work there.

India is made up with a lot of different cultures and states already. We cannot judge the whole country based on the actions of some people in one state, Assam. We have to understand the complexity of this whole situation without jumping to conclusions based on what perspective.

I agree.  If it's not broke, don't fix it. And the people protesting show that they are not open to the idea.  If its because of lack of understanding, they need to work on educating their people before pushing any Acts through.   If the Assam was failing somewhere, they should explain to the people to curve the confusion.
If the refugees get expelled, there will be issues. First it's muslims, later others. We can't tolerate religious bias which puts some people at a disadvantage

Because the accord has worked for thirty years, there is no need to believe that it was right or correct in its aims. The new act is just as bad but people seem to have a real issue with it now. People always lean on what is familar so they tend to want to dismiss the new act. The old accord sought to expel refugees based on religion and did so while the new act allows these people to stay and change the culture. I think that people are upset because they had a framework for years on how to deal with refugees and now that may be gone with this new act. Perhaps we need to take a step back and look at the past accord and see how bad this was for refugees and realize that we have evolved beyond this and should accept people regardless. the new act does not seek to change the country or its traditions but to merely allow for asylum seekers to have a home. Shouldn't this be our new aim for the country?
The actions of a few shouldn't be used to generalize a whole country of citizens. We should focus on the situation and try to find a way to manage all the parties contributing to the drama.

Why change the law now when its been unchanged since 1955? Talk about doing away with tradition. No wonder people are upset. This will change large parts of India! India is not used to bringing in so many different kinds of refugees!

It doesn't seem legitimate to shut down the internet in hopes to stop "misinformation," does it? The best way to battle bad speech is to allow more good speech. More speech is better. Always. And the internet is a vital channel for voices to be heard.
It is getting crazy in the world! I hope they can come to a peaceful resolution and not kill each other!

I agree completely. They had a system that, while flawed, more or less worked since before most of us were even alive. Did they not expect that radical change would lead to a radical response? This is what happens when like you say, they do away with tradition.
It's normal for people to want to go out. Having everything closed really affects people. Not just their social life, but livelihood as well.

It would've been nice if the article at least had a brief paragraph giving context to the lockdown. I had no idea this was a thing and from reading the article, no idea if it's related to a pandemic or some political event or what. Had to look it up myself, but anyway, sad news. Hope the situation resolved for these poor people sooner than later.

I understand the need to lock down in certain cases, but what about the people? There's no medical? There's no ATM cash? No markets? How will they survive? What are the odds of the people had a warning and were prepared?

Well I hate to see Asia and the Middle East in such turmoil. I'm sure the surrounding countries in that part of the world are suffering as well: since Kashmir is going though such a time it seems obvious that that part of the world is dealing with the same or similar problems. (I recently read about similar things going on in Syria too!) Let's hope they make it through to better times.

How far can lockdowns go? It starts with a few weeks, then it's months, and as noted here, there's no definitive end in sight. Before you know it, these governments will expect lockdowns to be the normal state of things with people living their entire lives indoors and maybe getting permission to venture outside every now and then.
The lockdown is a necessary evil. No one wants it, but they all need it. It is better than a ton of sick people overwhelming healthcare systems.

This was a great indicator of how harmful lockdowns could be, whether in response to politics or sickness or whatever else. It only brings about misery. We've seen it happen already, there's no reason to think it won't happen anytime such a suggestion is brought up.

This lockdown seems serious, doesn't it? When something like this happens it really makes you wonder if there's a better alternative. Are there just only two options - gritting teeth and bearing through or causing a full-blown revolt with potentially serious consequences? But, surely these aren't the only options during such a crisis. There must be other ways to navigate such difficult times. It's easy to feel trapped between gritting teeth and causing a revolt, but perhaps the real challenge is charting a different, more sustainable path through adversity. After all, aren't human beings capable of innovation and adaptability?

If the majority of the people accept the lockdown, maybe it is the best solution. The power of the people can often give a good result. The government often does the will of the people and maybe this solution is the best option.

There is a gaping lacuna in this article: the cause of purpose of the lockdown being described. Why is there such a severe lockdown? I read it twice, both times in vain, hoping to divine an answer. No dice. What is going on?

Kashmir is in a region known for political instability. A 2-month lockdown is extreme, because what happens if something happens in the future and you decide to lock down, how long then? They can stop public transportation? How long? A day, a month, a year?

It's good to be skeptical of outsiders coming into Africa and possibly using Africans as guinea pigs, but as long as proper protocols are followed and ethical standards are upheld, I think it would be unwise to not accept the outside money and the assistance of pharmaceutical companies in this instance. There need to be tests done to find a vaccine for this new virus, and it might as well be done in Africa.

Indeed, this situation could end up being a godsend for getting more funding for life-saving vaccines into more bodies on the continent. It seems like a great opportunity for a traditionally under-served people to get access to new medicine and new medical treatments.

I think this is a case of the media wanting to create a false narrative. There's been thousands and indirectly probably tens and hundreds of thousands of situations where a vaccine or an experiment or something new has had been tried out in medical history and undoubtedly you're going to find smattering of them have started out in Africa. The news is trying to portray it as if every time the medical community doesn't know the effect of something well let's just go test it on the black people in Africa. That's not what happens.

These are all cherry picked stories and events that the media is selectively using to push a predefined agenda they already wanted to push.
There hasn't been a big issue so far that people know about. The trials hold little risk. We can't discount the possibility.

They need to get over what happened in the past and realize they are needed for testing if they want vaccines for their people. If they don't comply with testing vaccines, their people will end up dying. How don't they get this? They can't just complain about what happened decades ago if they want progress, can they? Lives are on the line!

Medical experimentation has always been done on the less fortunate. It's almost tradition at this point. And for good reason. It's just mutually beneficial. We can eliminate the more exploitative factors while still pushing forward research and compensating people who need it most.
It's pretty simple. Testing is either done in Africa or it's not. Do we really have the whole picture? Are things transparent or is there more to this? It's either done secretively or openly.

Some companies, and countries think it is acceptable to experiment on africans. They've done it in africa, as well as in United states. It's time for that to end. I'm not sure what would make it seem Africa was the place to start. Other countries must have been experiencing similar numbers. So why was it not more evenly spread out? Articles like this are helpful. We need to be aware of what is happening and that is the beginning of fixing it.

Just because something has always been done, doesn't make it right. Why are the less fortunate or those in Africa the only ones we can use as test subjects? We should not use tradtion/history as an excuse to do wrong.

Don't these people have much bigger things to worry about than what hiccups could go along with experiments? This is Africa we're talking about. I mean, of course everything should be done to ensure any trials and experiments are conducted ethically, but with all the massive amounts of poverty and conflict these places are dealing with, this doesn't seem like it should be a huge priority.

This report should include comments on Bill Gates. I don't trust that guy, as he has "donated" lots of money to campaigns in Africa that sound good on paper but feel as exploitative as those described in this article. We should be wary, I think.

If there are going to be human test subjects at all, why not those who don't typically have access to good health care? There should be a balance between West and Africa, but I don't see a problem with underprivileged people worldwide consenting to a trial. The problem of past exploitation is a serious one, and informed consent should be a top priority, so I agree that just because something was done in the past doesn't make it right, but I can see how a testing program could be designed to be as humanitarian as possible for those who otherwise lack access to quality health care.

Why exactly are they the ones that need to be experimented on if they want vaccines for their people? Africans should get tested on so that Africans, Europeans, and Americans get vaccines? Why not conduct these fairly risky trials on Americans and then all those groups could get vaccines? The disparity in treatment is the whole point of the article.
Travel to Africa should be avoided if possible. Africa is such a vast place yet Ebola is concentrated there. We should not bring any instances of this disease back to our country.

Oh no, is it Ebola or covid, is it just one or the other? Don't they deserve a break? I'm sure that the lessons from Ebola will get them through covid. The people must be strong to have eradicated ebola. Because they deserve not to have to endure covid now. I'm sure the people are strong enough to get through it. Maybe maybe covid quarantine will be successful.

I have heard many groups online say COVID is a hoax. Are we even sure this is a problem? There is an article where a doctor known for alternative perspectives stated most of the positive tests are false. I think we need to look into this more before we panic.

COVID is nothing compared to Ebola, and as mentioned in the article, it has not been 42 days yet, so it could still come back. They should focus on making sure that doesn't happen and not on COVID. Just look at the infection rate and severity between the 2 and tell me why you should not still focus on Ebola!

I think it is only natural, people having just experienced one epidemic will be hyper vigilant about another. I believe their experience will give the citizens an advantage in preventing the spread of COVID. In fact, in some cases they may over react in cautionary measures, which is only natural given their recent experience with infectious disease.

It's good to hear that Congo has eradicated ebola. But now they have covid. Where will that end? They are not the first African nation to have received covid. But hopefully this is the last one. We don't need this to go any further. This is not good for the world.
I agree with that in general. But when it comes to Covid, it's already everywhere so that shouldn't be the reason to avoid traveling to just an African country.

Do the people of this country want to go through all of this all over again? Maybe they are only emboldened further to fight against COVID, but I feel like maybe they are tired of it all and the relative lack of danger compared to Ebola may make them not want to go through so many lockdowns and the like. These sorts of things should be put up to a vote, because the majority's opinion on what risks they're willing to take should be the most important.

I think the majority of the people in this country are very prepared for COVID since they have learned so much from Ebola battles. Those lessons have thought them how to deal with these infectious agents and how to prevent the spread.  Most of the people have learned from example about trusting Science and the medical community about how to eradicate these issues.

Considering how severe both Ebola and Covid diseases can be, Iâm actually not sure DR Congo is doing enough to fully address these major public health crises.  People who might have these diseases may need to be very carefully monitored and significant steps need to be taken that they donât give these diseases to uninfected people.  

True, the government is responding to these diseases with some public health requirements. This is not enough, however. Citizens themselves need to be proactive about their health, ensuring they stay well hydrated, sleep adequately each night, and consume enough nutritious foods with vitamins and minerals. Avoiding junk foods and focusing on high quality ingredients like fresh fruits and vegetables and whole grains will help the population boost its potential immunity levels and be in a state of less overall inflammation.
