This will let people take personal ownership of their health and have a better chance of recovering quickly should they be unlucky enough to get one of these viruses.

It is significant that in DR Congo vaccinations led to the defeat of a terrible infectious disease, but in America there is much resistance to the vaccines developed to combat the Coronavirus (Now termed COVID). It is important to learn from others. With modern transportation we are one world. What happens in any place can effect what happens in another. There is a need to cooperate and ensure that people worldwide share accurate information.

Let's hope they are able to contain and prevent its spread effectively. Their experience with Ebola may help guide them with this difficult task. It is disappointing to see this region have to face another deadly disease. It is important that we lend global support as needed to assist them.

This is an unprecedented virus and many people have different opinions on what should or should not happen to help protect people. I think too many people are took quick to criticize China without having better solutions. Now more than ever people need to come together and help support each other and focus energy on finding solutions instead of playing the blame game.

Better that millions of people in Wuhan are inconvenienced than a billion people in China. Better that a billion people in China are inconvenienced than 8 billion people around the world. Chinese government can afford the biggest Navy in the world and nuclear weapons and space program, they can afford masks etc. Shutting down internet is the move of an embarrassed government that doesn't want the outside world to know what is going on. Chinese citizens are more afraid of their government than anything else.

Wuhan was caught unprepared. Their knee jerk response only made things worse. The first thing they should have done was notify the hospitals to start tracking the numbers of patients with the disease. Once President Xi Jinping was briefed on the speed of the spread of the virus, he was the best source to disseminate the information. His expertise as a leader can guide the provinces through quarantines and other actions needed to slow down the spread.

I think it's pretty clear the government simply couldn't do more and those complaints are not really reasonable. It's easy for armchair experts with no understanding of the actual issue to make those kinds of comments, but it's not fair. Either they did what they did, which probably saved millions, or they did nothing and many more would have died. It's hard to see any other options.

The fact that the government was able to get away with this is crazy to me! millions of people died across the world due to authorities in China not being forthright about what was going on. We need to understand why Chinese citizens haven't demanded answers yet.

Its very sad that that China and its weak response to the pandemic has led the people of Wuhan down by not  giving them the appropriate medical and food supplies necessary to combat this disease. Fudging the numbers or ignoring the problem doesn't make it go away and to shutdown an entire city because of the pandemic it just makes the situation worse. Access to resources like medical treatments to those that need it the most is the appropriate action as oppose to shutting everything down.

Is the outbreak really this bad or is panic being used to attack the government? How can we know the real situation without research and facts? I am not trying to dismiss the severity but it is hard to judge with no verifiable information. We can either accept the fear or just dismiss the issue entirely. Neither seem like good options, so let's get the facts instead. Don't fall for the black and white thinking. Do your research, get the facts and find a solution.

It's wild to me that you think the government couldn't do more. We are talking about the Chinese government. Of course they could do more since they had information they were more than likely trying t suppress from the world about this virus and what it would do to a city. They could have used that information to begin to mobilize the equipment they would need in order to better support the residents of Wuhan once they knew they would quarantine and shit down the city. We all should stand with Wuhan and its residents at this moment. They have been let down by their government, and that saddens me.

The officials in Wuhan have quarantined the city prematurely. Perhaps this outbreak could have been contained without treating the people like prisoners. Certainly there were other things that could have been done in order to contain the virus that didn't make the people feel like they weren't appreciated. Maybe we could have tried some alternate medicine methods or something to treat it before quarantine.

I also feel the harshness of the quarantine measures was beyond what was necessary to address the outbreak. I don't know that alternative medicines would have been an effective option to address the outbreak either, but the government could have taken some measures that both addressed the potential seriousness of the virus while also respecting the basic rights and dignity of its citizens. Expanding health care options temporarily, making masks more readily available, and encouraging people who were feeling sick to limit their activity to staying home or seek medical care would have been a potential alternative way to deal with the crisis in a less brutal manner. This was a truly difficult time and the government had to make difficult decisions without a whole lot of time to think through the ramifications, but positive and direct communication with people in the city as well as neighboring areas would have cut down on anxiety and panic feelings, helping to improve things. Wuhan's residents were resilient during a really challenging period and should be praised for how well they persevered through the adversity.

It feels apocalyptic, doesn't it? Whole cities entirely shut down by the federal government of a country with many hundreds of millions of people. Let's hope this never happens again and that everyone affected by this disaster can recover as best as they can.

This is the expected consequence of taking such drastic, abnormal measures to try to contain a pandemic. We have immune systems for a reason. Of course, sensible measures like taking vaccines when they're available and not coughing in other people's faces and all that are great, but we should also let nature run its course before we put the entire world under such authoritarian measures.

It is natural to jump to the conclusion that all censorship is wrong. We have to stop attributing our own culture to totally different countries. What is right in one culture may not necessarily be the same in another.

Is Turkey not a democracy? If this is the government and subsequently the policies they voted for, what's the problem? The will of the Turkish people should be respected, even if they don't have the same values on things like free speech that these Western institutions are criticizing them for.
Censorship and strong hand ways have always been part of the Turkish way. Nothing to see here. People should expect this to be the way, as it's always been,.

Just because it's been that way doesn't mean it has to continue being that way. The Turkish people need to stand up to this using what little free speech they have remaining or the consequences will be dire. The repression will only grow further and further if it's not stopped before it's too late.

I agree that in most cases, you can't compare cultures with other cultures for different countries. Not everything should be compared like that. However, sometimes governments look to how others are ran and get ideas. So censoring for this country might be okay for them, another country will see how well it worked for them and want to do the same. It's important to find the balance and not disregard something as "That's what we do so it's wrong" or "That's what they do so it's up to them to figure out." In the end, something is being influenced. It is a delicate balance.

If the judges don't get involved at the beginning of the process isn't it just an open field to make accusations for whatever reason.  What we have here is a divide of two roads to go down.  Either make judging mandatory before taking stuff down or just let the corrupt free for all continue.

Turkey as a country has pretty bad human rights issues and is overall not a very nice place to live. Focusing their energy on this small issue is not a wise use of their time. Focus on your countries issue with how they treat women and dissent before something like this.

Are we really getting bothered about soccer matches? Especially, the right to illegally stream soccer matches? I mean, if they start abusing the law to go after what its intended purpose, that would be bad of course, but don't people, particularly Turkish people, have far bigger problems to worry about? This sort of 'censorship' is hardly meaningful in the face of what Turkey's current dictator is doing.
This is a standard Turk issue. They will restrict anything opposing the status quo. it's how the government can keep people in line. No other reason to block anything without a court order.

I see your point here, why should we care over the censorship of soccer matches being broadcast? That is very fair, but I think there is a bigger point being made here that you are potentially overlooking. This may seem like a small thing, but it is just a symptom of the growing authoritarian government style in Turkey. Even if it is not the most major problem in all of Turkey, there is plenty of resources to deal with all problems. The more problems we can address then the better the society in general will function. That is the hope at least, that if we can bring back even small freedoms to Turkey that larger ones will follow.
They can now ban sites that broadcast matches. The next thing they'll do is ban any mention of football if they don't align with the government.

Do people really think they need to be empowering football organizations of all things in the name of oppression? Maybe other uses of these laws are bad, but I somehow doubt the football organizations are going to do anything but block illegal broadcasts, like they claim. And should they not? The concept of needing a court order to block a live stream on a time-sensitive sports match doesn't seem sensible.
There are more things to worry about than conspiracies. For now, these are all theories. How about they focus on things that economic issues directly impacting them?

The people just need to wait for the process to play out. The court made a good decision that they agree with, so those in charge obviously know what they're doing and what is right. Trust in the process and trust in the system and another good decision will follow. They are the ones making the decisions for a reason!

All this commotion over some mild disputes on privacy versus security? Doesn't India have more pressing problems? I mean, data privacy is important, but I feel like the Indian government should be more focused on things like the extreme poverty they've got, the violent campaigns against minorities, and other such things that seem a lot more important.

I think not knowing if their government has their back in the event of a data breach of if they don't even know what their government does with their data, does affect them. They can focus on multiple things at once. Data breaches and whatnot can cause a person a lot of suffering.

But the processes are happening exactly because people were complaining in the first place. Public pressure is necessary for systems to act. I don't think it makes much sense to say they should just stop worrying now because the system can sort itself out.

The fact that there are members of the Srikrishna Committee who didn't help with the Aadhaar Act implies the committee is unbiased. These members are proof that the committee is focused on safeguarding privacy rights and that all members of the committee are on board. If they members who helped draft the Aadhaar Act were against ensuring privacy rights are protected, they wouldn't allow neutral members on the board, would they? Since they did, we can safely say that every member is a die-hard protector of citizens' privacy rights even if they don't say it outright. Their actions speak for themselves.
It's natural to question the status quo. So people will need better definitions of data sensitivity. Privacy is always paramount in protecting individual liberties.

It sounds like much of the criticisms about all this are pretty minor and not something to be that concerned about. The country has to pass laws related to all this kind of stuff. Like most laws, it's probably not going to be perfect, but what else can they do? Whatever they do, someone will complain about it, so they either do nothing or just let the courts go through with the process.

It's just like if a bunch of people who don't understand medicine tried to diagnose a patient in front of a doctor, they would just complicate the situation. It's more productive to have faith in the skills and knowledge of those we employ to manage these systems. They were trained for this and are the very best at what they do. They were trained for that! Remember, armchair experts often overlook the years of study these professionals have.

Waving off concerns as too simplistic may harm the efforts for overall freedom in the long term. The battle no matter how small should be done and never disparaged. Don't discount the small steps of progress, they can add up.

Governance by committee is no good. Let the people decide. Draft up definitions for the terms in question and an outline of what the restrictions and proscriptions are to be, and let the people vote. The voice of the majority will be the truest guide in a situation like this one. The collective wisdom of the many is more insightful than the few.

I completely agree with you. Privacy is one of the most fundamental rights and it's really a time-honored tradition that people of all cultures have adopted. Digital space should not be treated differently as the private physical spaces we've respected for so many generations. Whatever laws these committees come up with, hopefully, they should respect that.
No one should be forced to give this information. There are downsides to everything. It should be optional.
The countries taking in refugees have more to worry about. Making sure they are accounted for, is essential. The problem of invisible refugees outweighs their privacy in a country they breached.

How much deeper are we going to dig into relying on artificial technologies for every little thing? Applications of these sorts of unnatural things really dehumanize people. These people are right to be worried, because they're being turned from real individuals into some digital statistic in a machine.
Refugees do not have inherent rights, other than human rights. They are not entitled to anything. So there are more crucial things to worry about in the society.
You can either join the new technology or get left behind. There is to middle ground with tech. There is not as much balance as many think.

I think I agree, but I think that's more something the people of the country should decide. It sounds like this is more a move by the UN than the actual countries themselves. Why don't their people put it to a vote? Majority opinion should be the deciding factor here, like everything else in a true democracy.
Refugees have more to worry about than privacy. They are running from home, and don't want their host to know who they are? There are worst issues for the host, if they can't identify refugees.

They are refugees in an extremely poor country, which means they come from even poorer ones and they are worried about an ID? How about focusing on just finding food, shelter, and a way out of violent countries before caring about having your eyes scanned and whatnot!? The security concerns are worrisome, I get that, but its preferable over being homeless and starving!

There seem to be a Eritrean and Sudanese refugees in ethiopia. I'm in the United States and I wasn't aware of this. But we have refugees in this country. And generally they would like to keep their information private is what I would like to think. Everyone has the right to privacy. So let's let these people keep their dignity and privacy.

What a spot to occupy, truly that between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand you need safety and the things required to survive, and on the other you would like to protect your private (biometric) data. This system doesn't seem tolerant of people who lean a little more toward the latter. That seems like a real problem, one which demands attention.
This just has bad news written all over it. Its not safe for anyone really

It's unfortunate the system isn't working as it should because in theory it is a good idea. The more organizations know about a particular refugee, the better the organization can serve them. But if the organizations are asking for too much information, or aren't being transparent about risks, or aren't actually providing a better service, then the entire program needs to be retooled. A program with that fully informs of implications and offers an opt-in option could balance efficiency and individual concerns.

Facebook has long held that controversial posts will be monitored and/or removed. This is hardly new. They've come under fire for similar things in other regions of the world, many times, because this has been their way, their modus operandi, from almost the beginning. It seems irrational and unfair to react with shock when Facebook is only acting according to its longtime practice and standard operation.

So true! It is hard to believe that this censorship that Facebook is doing is still happening.  What happens next? Do they censor all political names so when anyone talks about any figure they get censored? This is going to lead to mass hysteria when no one can get any truthful information. Chaos will reign! Everyone being blindsided by what is and isn't true, the government wants to confuse people to have total control over them. Let's not let this happen! We have to fight this!

Facebook goes too far. Sison means something to a lot of people in the philippines. So they should be allowed to post about him in the philippines. The people respected him, and Facebook should allow people to share. He simply counts as a political figure. Facebook should back down.

Facebook has always picked certain people or opinions they deem to be unacceptable, and flag posts which contain or promote them. This is Facebook's culture and modus operandi. It has been that way from the beginning. We can't be surprised and dismayed that they are taking such actions now, given this is their long-standing practice, rooted in their corporate culture. I would recommend moving to another platform. But I wouldn't expect Facebook to change any more than an old tree might change its bark. Traditions are very stubborn things.

Totally agree. If it happened here, it is undoubtedly happening everywhere across the world. Maybe Facebook should do away with any form of moderation or censorship. We should of course consider the consequences, but in this case the pros may outweigh the cons.

I agree that Facebook monitors things a little too far at times. Think about the alternative of everyone posting whatever they wanted. Without some line in the sand, criminals and anyone else could post whatever illegal images they wanted. Think about actions that not censorship would have on Facebook, and social media in general. It is scary to think about. I am not even saying that all posts would go into the wild west territory and be harmful, but the few cases that I have seen of misuse it's a reasonable fear. Let's not ignore the risks!

Social media should not be blocking content unless it is violent or is about a child. Posting about a political figure should not be taken down. Dissenting opinions should not be removed.  Diverse viewpoints keep thinking and debate alive. We need to hear from different people with different views.

It's not a good look when a company like Facebook sets up auto-flagging protocols like this. However, a bigger problem is those countries in which Facebook is not even allowed. What's worse, the problem described in this story (auto-flagging) or a complete social media blackout? Let's keep our priorities in view at all times. It seems there's always a bigger fish to fry.

Whenever I hear about automated censorship on social media platforms, it's always targeting the wrong people. It clearly is a system that doesn't work well, and probably never will. Companies should just ditch the idea and get back to human moderation.

And Facebook's culture is wrong.  Its really that simple.  Just because it has always been done doesn't mean that it should be done.    Sometimes a tradition is just stupid.     As Shirley Jackson pointed out in The Lottery.    And this is really hurting people.   It warps history to fit a clean, sanitized narrative.   It removes nuance and subtlety.    Proper representation of history is important. Especially on our new communication platforms that are the main way people share information these days.

The act of censorship by social media platforms like Facebook is concerning. This can influence how history is remembered and potentially eradicate important viewpoints and voices. Free speech should be valued, and discussions must be prompted, not suppressed. Respect for Sison's legacy should be allowed, as should discourse on his political ideology. Everyone deserves respect in their passing, even if their beliefs or actions may be controversial.

The people of the Philippines should be allowed to honor an important figure such as Sison.  Not everyone has to like him for this to be allowed, and Facebook has overstepped a boundary by such censorship.  Maybe if people boycotted Facebook they'd get the picture and reconsider their policies.  It is high time we put forth the need for balanced discourse where different views are allowed.

Journalists should not be fearing for their lives just by doing their job. It is unthinkable to consider that reporters are arrested, attacked and murdered routinely in Cameroon. These sorts of threats and violence goes against all of the natural world. It is completely unnatural and is repulsive to our natural instincts. Instead we must protect these journalists as we would our own family. This is what we must do as humans, it is only natural. Do you all agree on this simple notion?

It seems normal for any person or group in power to protect that power. We see this behavior across the animal kingdom, so why are we surprised when it occurs within our own species? In some parts of the world there have been more successful attempts at taming this tendency. But perhaps rule by might has more going for it than people think. Look at Rome and the worldwide peace its rule by might established. And there is more than historical examples, as one can also include the United States in such a list.

This just seems to be another typical result of colonialism. Is it ever any different? I feel like all the news I see suggests not. The impacts of colonial rule are always just that of suffering and injustice.
All those thousands of dead, for no good reason. I feel like the only real choice here is to have an international coalition intervene. That is the only way to avoid more mass death and destruction.

We live in a time where we shout freedom of speech from the rooftops until someone says something thatâs not flattering.where we have  Thatâs a slippery slope because where does it stop why even have a news channel if you only want people to say things that paint you in a positive light. Pretty soon the news wonât be looked at as facts only fantasy.
Because we are not animals you bootlicker. If you need to suppress the truth to remain in power, then you need to be removed. We have the ability to be better, and we should be held as such.

Any sane human being should be horrified by these journalists losing their lives for telling the truth, but we must face a larger problem, that of deaths from poverty in Cameroon. Thousands of people die from not having enough food and clean water in Cameroon every single year. That seems like a much more urgent problem that the admittedly horrific murder of a few journalists, and we must slay the giant before battling the elves.

Just because something is normal or happened in the past doesn't mean it's something we should encourage or tolerate. We worked hard to move away from systems like these. And Rome doesn't seem like the greatest example. The millions of bodies it took to create it and the fact that it's no longer around says more than whatever peace it maintained.

I agree completely. Colonialism really seems to be the trunk of the issues here, but what about the root? Shouldn't there be a focus on what is causing colonialism in the first place? In the global space, there are issues like hunger, incurable diseases, and rampant corruption that are much much worse but aren't considered. These issues seem like they are never ending but if we think about it, they get less attention compared to colonialism. Wouldn't you consider them more important? Imagine the effort spent on decolonization being redirected to those problems? They could be solved in no time and the domino effect of those issues being solve might shift to colonialism being solved as well. It might be worth looking into, don't you think?

Lots of us in the US take our 1st amendment rights for granted. What happened to these journalists could just as easily be any one of us if we were born somewhere else! Being a journalist in countries without freedom of speech or with a government that is hostile to them is very brave.

It's fallacious to say that we must focus on some bigger problem before we can worry about a problem. While it's terrible for people to die from poverty and starvation in Cameroon, it's equally terrible for people's freedoms to be repressed and journalists and others arrested and killed for it. We can focus on both at the same time. Journalists like Lambert Kehven, Samuel Wazizi, and Kingsley Fomunyuy are courageous individuals who brought truth to light, and we should support them in the fight for their cause. The suppression and terror they and others have faced is not a secondary issue but a horrifying reality that demands our immediate attention and response. It's high time we raise our voices and act now before it's too late!

What's the point of having journalists in a particular country if they can't report anything? This situation speaks volumes about the state of press freedom, which is supposedly guaranteed by the constitution. As CPJ stated, journalists are not terrorists, yet they are treated as such in Cameroon. Imagine if other countries began to follow the same trend because they saw no repercussions on such acts? That's a chilling perspective for the future of global journalism. As the UN recognizes, an independent press is crucial to preserving human rights - but it feels like that message is getting lost somewhere in the narrative.
It seems like the right choice was made in this situation. to withdraw the bill because it was overreaching The best start.

I think this is very good sign that they are withdrawing the bill and having debate on it.  It prevents a slippery slope that leads to less freedom of speech.  It is good sign that they can debate it even during such a once in a lifetime event like COVID which can increase the support of otherwise very restrictive measure against freedom. The slope can get very slippery and once it starts it is hard to go back.

It's only natural that the government wants to control the narrative about their machinations.  That's the way governments usually work (but not all have bad intentions).  They've always been crooked and not really concerned about the common people and their freedoms. As nature takes its course, so do institutions.  However, this doesn't negate the need for persistent vigilance and insistence on transparency and accountability.

The Tunisian government officials that withdrew the bill made a good decision by pulling it from consideration. It is obvious that a group like the ACLU would definitely denounce this bill, so you know it's a terrible law. I was already skeptical of the bill, but when I realized they would agree with me it became obvious and clear. This sort of restriction on speech is scary and should always be avoided. The more we restrict speech the more problems we always create. While I understand why government officials are concerned with misinformation we must be careful in how we address this. Only with a group effort of experts, government official and civilians can we solve this ongoing problem. Does anyone disagree with this approach? Can we all agree on this and find a middle ground together where free speech is protected and disinformation is eliminated?

Obviously this would negatively impact the vast majority of politically active citizens while only helping the politicians. This should have been withdrawn and it never should be introduced again.  You would have a hard time finding a citizen okay with this, but I'm sure there are a few of the couple hundred politicians who are. Citizens outnumber them by a mile.

I agree that it's good that this bill was withdrawn but who is to say where it stops? The issue now becomes what other laws can the people find to challenge and have withdrawn? Are we going to petition for leniency in burglary or tax evasion laws just because we don't agree with them? Would murder be considered fair? It's crucial to note that this could pave the way to utter chaos where anyone with a slick lawyer could get away with ruthless crimes. The direction we are headed in is scary!

This is proof that if the people speak up, they can get things done! The power of social media and the internet has made all this possible. If this were 20-30 years or so ago, most probably wouldn't have even known about the bill. More like this needs to happen in other countries!

Governments that attempt to support human rights are a model for the rest of the world. As a certain peace ambassador I admire once put it, it requires immense strength to prioritize the needs of others. Kudos to Tunisia for not only fostering such strength, but also for their unwavering commitment to equality and justice. Their administration exemplifies dedication to human rights. If the rest of the world took a leaf out of their book, imagine the progress we could achieve?

i guess the age old adage of believe none of what you hear and half of what you see stands true. one should seek several different sources when obtaining information and/or news. we should be prompted not to accept everything at face value.

I am definitely a supporter of governments that support human rights, I think that most people in the world feels the same. I just don't understand your thought process here, how exactly are you labeling Tunisia as one? They are clearly try to restrict free speech with this newly proposed law, everyone knows that misinformation or disinformation is incredibly difficult to label. Secondly, who is this peace ambassador you are referencing? It doesn't add to your argument when you give credibility to some anonymous expert. Can you see where I am coming from on this? Wouldn't you want to know who this expert was if you were in my shoes? I, for one, am glad that this bill has been withdrawn and we need to make sure it stays that way. Let's band together and find out the best way to make Tunisia an actual beacon for freedom, equality and justice!

I'm relieved there was significant pushback on this proposed legislation. It's not unreasonable to predict that if the law had passed without controversy, other countries will be inspired to enact similar legislation in order to suppress dissident voices. Then what? A world where free expression is limited in the name of stopping fake news? Let's keep pushing for freedom of speech.

It's good that the protests of the people were heard and this bill is being reconsidered.  The bill would have allowed the government and politicians to get away with too much.  There should be a way for people to express their opinions and a bill to criminalize it seems far too much. I hope the Tunisian government will find more democratic ways to combat disinformation, perhaps through better education or stricter protocols for news sites.

Combating fake news is important, but this happened during covid, when thousands of people were dying. The government was focused on punishing journalists and not spending all their time and effort on helping control the virus and save the people? Absurd. Shows they don't care for their own people!

I think I kind of agree with the government here. It felt like every other article I was ever linked about COVID was some denialist fake news. Extend that to the world and there were probably billions of fabricated articles spread around globally. Some action does need to be taken.

Covid-19 affects a lot of people. The majority of people want to know that the information they read on covid-19 is accurate. In fact all people who take the time to read something with covid-19 want it to be accurate. 12 in 19 is a very important topic. We need to make sure there is no fake news.

The government should have no control over the media. If the government could be trusted that would be a different story but governments across the globe have proven time and again that they can't be so we need to have many opinions and freedom of press. A free and diverse media allows for a informed public and keeps everyone free.

Those in power have always been punitive towards those who criticize them. And in that part of the world, such an approach is the settled, long-standing way of doing things. We can't expect them to turn on a dime, can we? Let's be patient while we encourage them to embrace a different tradition, one which protects the freedom of the press as much as the power held by the central authority. Changing inherited practices takes time and effort, after all.

This kind of censorship is always only the start. Today it's so-called misinformation related to the pandemic, but what about tomorrow? As the article demonstrates, it's already being stretched to cover some criticism of government behavior. Before you know it, it's not just pandemic related. Anything bad about the government is suddenly 'misinformation'.

When you allow the government to take control of freedom of speech it will lead to much worse problems. Who is to decide what is fake news about Covid or any other issue? Regardless, it is up to the people to determine if it is true or not. If the authorities are allowed to punish people for freely speaking online where does it go? How much worse will it get?

The road to totalitarianism begins here, with a clamping down on independent journalism. Once freedom of the press is stamped out, then comes freedom of speech, then the freedom to assemble, to protest, etc., etc. Soon a state of crushing authority will dominate the people in all areas of their lives. That is why the road must be destroyed here, at the start, so the people have a shot at remaining free.

And you trust the governments, especially relatively authoritarian and corrupt governments like these, to tell people what is fake and what isn't? The article notes out all the problems with that. This sort of rhetoric often just leads to suppressing political dissent.

COVID has turned a lot of countries into borderline authoritarian places to live. The people of Malaysia need to make sure their government doesn't get away with any kind of censorship or they will just keep doing it. Freedom of speech is the most important part of a civilize society, so allowing the government to trample on that will lead to them trampling on other rights as well.

Malaysians should be very wary. Authoritarianism always starts small, like this. First it's just so-called misinformation related to COVID, but what's next? Before you know it, so much as saying you don't think the government is doing a great job is an offense and all dissenting voices will be silenced.

I would say that the majority of people would agree that fake information circulating during the COVID pandemic is a major problem. However, the measures by the Malaysian government is much too draconian. This is a blatant infringement on free speech and the freedom of the press.

El Salvador has a recent history of being a very violent and crime infested place.  I know several refugees from there that live in my hometown and they talk about how dangerous it was.  So I think that a majority of the people there do not mind giving up some civil rights in order to have a a safer country.  It is just a natural thing to do.  At some point a balance does need to be reached, but what good are civil rights in a country that is so dangerous.

If the country has been peaceful for nearly three decades, why stop it. Its methods must be working to some degree and shouldn't be punished. Other aspects of rights shouldn't be ignored but don't forget about peace being a large positive.

This article seems wildly biased, to the point of revulsion. I mean, they describe this man as having never gotten a degree and leave it at that, like he's a lesser person with no place in his position. How about pointing out that he dropped out of college to lead some successful businesses? Or that he spent years in successful years as a mayor, in two different municipalities?

I agree with you, and it's evident that you're right because the people support this government. Isn't it clear that they're willing to trade in some freedom for security? While this may be contrary to say American values, that doesn't mean it's wrong. If the majority of people are behind this kind of authoritarianism, it should be respected.

It's about time the international community and citizens of El Salvador demanded more. This kind of unchecked power is dangerous and the focus should be on creating a democratic state where power is balanced, not hogged by a few. When there is justice and equity, only then can true peace prevail. And for this to happen, international pressure plays a key role, don't you all agree?

The country had been so peaceful throughout the years, wonder what changed? Could be the uptick of crime and violence that have to be stopped. I had an old co-worker that came from El Salvador and he would tell me how great it was to live there before he moved. In 1985, he came to America for a better life. It was much more calm then. His cousin, although he isn't an expert officially, has been in law enforcement there for years. He claims that the crime rates are unbelievably high. I think his views on the situation really lend weight on my belief of what is happening.
Most experts think he is not so bad. So he is probably not as extreme as that. He is just a bitcoin shiller and focuses on that online.

The man seems to know what he's doing. Populism is taking over in so many countries recently because people are fed up with the status quo. I would trust Bukele over whomever was in power prior to this. I've read about what he's done to lower crime, and its great! Maybe that country NEEDED a little authoritarianism?

While all the centralized power this government has seems pretty problematic, the 'digital authoritarianism' bit seems pretty weak. Is this really a big and important part of the problem these people are facing? It feels like the more traditional authoritarian methods are significantly more important to deal with than how some people are treated online.

I agree. Although social media can be a dangerous tool, it remains a tool anyone can use and framing Bukele's use of that tool as something authoritarian just because he's especially good at is isn't productive. Misinformation and disinformation should be curtailed, including undue influence, but you can't stop someone from finding clever ways to spread their message. 

That said, it's not as though governments should let problematic social media influence run rampant. There needs to be sensible regulations even granting the freedom of people to spread their message.
Only focusing on the big problems may let many smaller solvable ones last longer then they should. Attack all problems if possible. A healthier system may be the result.

That's fine to say at the early stages. Wait until the authoritarianism only grows and grows, as this article describes. When has a rise in authoritarianism ever ultimately led to good results? It's a disturbing trend and people need to be aware of the threats posed by these sorts of modern populists.

If a presidential candidate is going to be voted on just by people of their ethnicity that means that Macedonia is a divided country susceptible to bias. Perhaps this is something they should work on so that they can choose candidates based on merit rather than their genes. Racial bias is something that should be addressed all over the world so that we can move forward as a human race.

People are  naturally distrustful of new things like this political system. It makes sense that people may not want to vote. It is important to encourage people to vote in order to achieve what the people want.

i find the "40 percent minimum" rule very interesting.  i wouldn't think that it would be so hard to get 40 percent of the electorate to vote but since the "first round" only brought out about 41 and a half percent, it presents a challenge.  it reminded me that although presidential elections in the US  get more than 40 percent, many people still don't take advantage of their precious right to vote.  i also find it interesting to compare the low voter turnout mentioned in this article to South Africa, which has a voter turnout of 66 percent.  it makes me wonder why some countries have a much higher turnout than others.

I agree, the country is divided and needs to move on with the times. It's not right that someone can't be in power just because of their skin color. It's awful that race is keeping the people from getting someone in office that is well qualified.

Perhaps it screams racial bias but we will have to dig deeper to truly find out. I don know if we can make that assumption off of one election. There is obviously distrust of government and we don't know what platforms these candidates are presenting. Maybe it just happens to be that they are putting forth legislation that will benefit people of their ethnicity. Or perhaps giving them a voice that has been silent for a long time. I'm sure all minority candidates campaign in a similar way when it comes to their constituents.

I agree with you completely. Who might win these elections seems like a lot less of an issue than why people are voting based on ethnic concerns. All the candidates should come together to focus on fixing that, as well as all the more important non-race related issues I know the country has, as they can only lead to terrible things down the road.
We really should get away from the idea that it's right to vote for somebody just because they share the same skin color or ethnicity has others. Seems like we excuse this type of behavior.

Saying they have racial bias loses a bit of nuance. Just like in the developed countries like America, people who come from a certain group understand and care about the issues relating to that group more than people outside of it. Macedonians voting for a Macedonian who they feel represents them well is no different from African Americans voting for African American candidates. Of course it would be ideal if the entire world were colorblind, but that's not the real world and people have to look out for their own interests in what ways they can.

For sure, not participating in democratic processes like voting doesn't just lead to social chaos and regret, it can potentially pave the way for unqualified leaders to take power. We've seen this happen in various countries around the globe. Inexperienced leadership leads to poorly drafted policies that fail to reflect the public's needs, thus triggering economic downturns and inflation. This can further balloon into increased unemployment rate, widening gap between the rich and poor, and could even escalate into mass unrests and protests. This snowball effect could ultimately result in the complete collapse of societal order. Hence, it is crucial that we don't underestimate the power of a single vote.
All I can say is that I hope the best for the country. Elections are stressful times but I hope for the best outcome for the citizens!

North Macedonia's challenging past makes for a troubling present. The ethnic and religious divisions that shattered Yugoslavia into pieces like Macedonia seem to linger. It's a place where a war criminal can become an MP and where ethnic nationalism is part of party's platform. What the country needs is unity among the different religious and ethnic groups, and political stability. This is accomplished easier with the Social Democrat candidate, but the country still has a way to go before it is fully unified. Stay strong, Macedonia.

That's part of the point I think. It seems that only one side seems to think it is okay to vote along racial lines, just like in the US. African Americans are said to be "supportive of their race" when they vote for candidates that are the same race that they are, but if whites vote for white people then they are seen as "racist". I think it is a bit more than just "voting for someone that is of the same race I am because they know what I go through" I think if more people were in fact color blind as you said, it would be better, but I think there is a lot of outside forces that make it seem like it is a both sides type issue. That is what seems to be happening here there is one side that is only supported by their own racial similars and a backlash of non-similars instead of looking at policies that would benefit everyone. Hopefully Macedonians and people all over the world can start looking at inclusivity as a norm that all people take part in instead of forcing it from whichever race or creed happens to have a majority in the country. Only then can a democracy flourish.

Great news for most of these people. Donald Trump was wildly dangerous and it's sensible for our nearest neighbors to have strong opinions on the election. Imagine how much worse things could have gotten for them if he won again. The wave of authoritarianism would likely hit these vulnerable countries, cursing them with leaders possibly even worse than Trump. All of the Americas could have fallen to catastrophic conflict and ruin.

Itâs funny how America is a joke to many people trying to come over here and live. The World seems to center around the United States, doesnât it? Maybe we are like reality television so bad itâs good?

Good or bad, expressing oneself through memes has become a norm nowadays, it's a natural form of communication. Hence, no matter the content of the memes, it's part of human nature to adapt and express ourselves. However, just like in nature where certain behaviors can be harmful (like a snake's venomous bite), some memes can perpetuate negativity and misinformation. Similarly, while it's a natural form of expression, sharing demeaning or offensive memes can ignite harmful thoughts or behaviors in others. So, while it's natural, we should still exercise caution and discernment in both creating and sharing memes.

People being allowed to express themselves is vital but not everyone is funny. People need to be able to post funny memes that appeal to the masses and not depressing ones that reflect our reality. There are only two types of memes, funny or depressing.

As an American, I find it fascinating to peek into what people in other places think about our election season. It brings about a better balance when you consider politics at home in light of a broader perspective. Also, the memes are pretty funny. If you got 'em, share 'em!

Does anyone else think we're going too far with making everything a joke and a meme and all that? Serious issues get made fun of constantly. Where will it end? I feel like if 9/11 happened today, the internet would be flooded with 'funny' memes about it by the end of the day. Eventually, nobody will take anything seriously and we'll all suffer from poor governments because we'll be treating everything like a joke.

This was a fun article but here is a nitpick: the popularity of online memes and Facebook posts is not a reliable guide to public opinion. What would be helpful is a citation from an expert in Latin American culture and political opinion, someone who studies the trends and knows the numbers - someone like Dr. Pablo Gomez, for instance. But there's nothing like that in this piece, so while I enjoyed it, I take it with a boulder of salt.
The leaders are in charge because they know what to do. They like Biden over Trump, so it must be the correct choice.

I agree. Comics have a long standing rule that states a good joke makes you the target and not the audience. It's sad to see that tradition go away for cheap laughs at someone elses' expense. I am not sure when that was lost in the comedy world, but it had its costs. It could dramatically alter the comic genre and not for the better. Remember the days when comedians would push the boundaries of their imaginations for a creative and non-insulting punchline? Now that was real entertainment! What do you think?

They don't have to be a reliable guide.  No one is using them as a scientifically perfect source.    They're a snapshot of what people are expressing.       The loudest people don't always represent the majority,  but they're the ones who control the conversation.    The great thing about international facebook memes is that we can see how various cultures differ from our own,  and how they're similar.

Are you saying that leaders are always right? I don't think that's the case just because they happen to be in charge at a certain time. We shouldn't take anyone's word at face value just because they're in charge of things, least of all politicians.
I am glad that Biden won the election. Glad to see Latin America having fun with the election as well. Politics can always do with a bit of levity.

People for the most part have always cared about wildlife and this should be no different. People need to make sure that they are doing what they can to protect animals and the environment because even if you say you don't care at some point it is going to affect you and the people that you care about. The present condition of the Earth should be alarming to all and make us all want to do better.

If this is because of whatever agricultural practices, it seems like the people simply don't value these animals. After all, the country is a democracy, so they voted for those policies. If that changes, it should only be if most people assess the situation and decide that flamingos and whatever other animals are more important. Not because some minority of activists force a change.

These poor baby flamingos in Anatolia are just the beginning. The drought that they are experiencing is being experienced in Parts the US too. The water in parts of the US is needed for animals, and humans. This is very serious. Climate change is creating a lot of trouble for a lot of people all over the world.

There is something else at play here, an underlying and perhaps unseen cause, as is often the case in situations like these. We should prepare for similar scenes all around the world where flamingos live (and die). This event signals not only the underlying cause but that it will soon likely manifest in many tragedies in various former flamingo paradises. Expect a global phenomenon, and prepare for it.

This is just one small part of what will happen if we don't reign in the climate. Today it's a bunch of dead flamingoes. What tomorrow? Other birds. Then horses. Cats and dogs. Finally, all of us people will be the victims of broken ecosystems.

It's really sad that this is happening at Lake Tzu but it also happens all over the world in other areas. Either we come together to help solve these problems, or we just continue to till every animal slowly dies out. Should we do stricter regulations? Frankly, I think we should rehome every single animal on the planet to a different one! That's obviously impractical, right? This is a huge dilemma! There's nothing else that we can do at this point!

This one bird species had thousands die in one area. That is a dangerous president and is only going to get worse if we don't do something about our farming practices and the environment. Losing animals like this cannot become normal and commonplace.

That's so sad to think about all of those beautiful birds suffering. Its even sadder to think about how stories like this will become more common as climate change gets worse. At this point, though, I think its unavoidable. We can't undo decades and decades of harm to the environment. But the politicians can make it harder for companies to abuse the environment now.

It's a travesty what we're doing to our natural ecosystems. How many more animals do we need to massacre before more people decide to deal with climate change? All of this because of all the artificial products we dump everywhere we can. We need to change. The power is in our hands to secure a sustainable future.

The country may be a democracy,  but that doesn't mean that people don't care.    It just means that they're not thinking about the long term consequences of their decisions.   That's why government regulations exist,  because people as individuals have a lot of difficulty considering the aggregate consequences of major decisions.   There should be stricter regulations to protect these animals.

It is horrific to see any animal die, when it's thousands of baby flamingoes, it's a pure tragedy. We should spend the time and resources to understand what happened, but there is a catch. While this is a tragedy there are major issues that are happening in Turkey, I don't think we can afford to put all our energy into what happened at Lake Tuz. We have the government of Turkey turning more authoritarian seeming by the day, shouldn't that come first here? Flamingoes and other wildlife matter, but the stability of the country must come first. How about we turn Turkey back into the democracy we all love and then implement changes to restore our beloved environment? If we can do that, we will can have both our freedom AND nature, who could argue against that?

We shouldn't adopt such a defeatist attitude. On the contrary, terrible stories like this should spur us into action. Keeping our natural resources and wildlife safe is everyone's responsibility. This needs to be a wake up call against poor environmental stewardship.

If it is the usual practice and preference of the people to dispose of their trash as they wish, it's hard to imagine why things should be different. When a culture has been doing something for such a long time, perhaps the government should devise a way of working around such a practice.

This failure clearly shows that waste reduction policies don't work and shouldn't be implemented anywhere else in the world. Maybe with some modifications it could work better, but overall there is likely no point to banning plastic or trying to reduce its use, given these results.

I don't understand, why doesn't the government put some recovery policies in place? Surely most people would be in support of that, right? The government should take a vote, or at least run some polling. If the majority wants change, which I think they definitely would, then they should implement that change rapidly.
The Burundi people should listen to their government. Obey the laws set forth and only good things should happen. Respect for laws leads to peace which helps everyone.

I agree that the government has to improve their recover policies, however I disagree with putting so much weight on the majority aspect of this issue. While the majority of the people often tend to agree on subjects it doesn't mean that they are correct in their judgement. I believe it is important for us to think independently and that we should elevate independent voices whenever we can. People who think differently can help us learn and grow as a culture. Also we can get caught up in group thought which can end up being very destructive in certain instances. Can you see where I am coming from on this?

We need to get a system in place. Everyone knows that bottles being littered along the ground is bad for us all, so we need to do something. Lets get more places to dispose of them, lets pay people to clean them up, ect. There is plenty we can do.
Recycling is very important to protecting our environment. We need to make sure that people are using recycled material and reusing things. If people don't recycle pretty soon it will be too late.

It's time for the government to step up and do something.  Their plan is obviously not working.  They need to come up with a recycling program that is not only good for the environment, but good for it's people.  When products go bad because they are not sterilized properly, it's even worse the environment.  It's time for them to come up with another plan.  The 51 tons of waste produced every day is only going to grow.  The government needs to do something before it gets to be a bigger problem.

I get what you are saying and most of it does make a lot of sense. I just would not put so much weight on what the majority of people want. At times the majority have had some rather terrible ideas, they were able to use their combined weight to force them into existence. I don't feel as if this is one of those cases, but we should always be cautious in our approach to such matters. It never hurts to use some critical thinking, right?

People complain about the US and our levels of pollution and whatnot, but when you compare it to most other countries in the world, the US looks perfect. Developing countries have a very long way to go. I think the US and other 1st world countries should do something to help these poor countries learn how to properly handle this kind of issue.

Plastic recycling is very important, they got to get the example from some other countries that emphasize on recycling. This is also a wake-up call to business which should follow in MERU investments' footsteps and implement effective bottle management policies. Stricter enforcement of littering fines could also work wonders. While appreciating the efforts by state and NGOs in providing trash cans in Bujumbura city center, it would be ideal to have these extended to the provinces. Raising an environmentally aware citizenry through education programs could also go a long way. Turnaround is possible!

I think this is clearly untrue given that in a lot of other places, for example in parts of America, these bans have been very effective. It's not fair to judge a policy solely based on how it plays out in one particular place. If anything, we should be trying to figure out why it didn't work here and learn from that, so that these important policies are more and more effective in the future.

I applaud the efforts to change to renewable energy sources. It does make one wonder how this will impact the economy of nations so dependent on oil. Despite short-term challenges, this transition will likely open doors for innovative opportunities and astounding economic growth. It's the smart choice to adapt to change and a sustainable future rather than risk being left behind with dwindling oil reserves. This shift could radically reshape economies for the better.

It's impressive to see the advancements made by Jordan. Very inspiring to see a country doing its thing when its neighbors are lagging behind. Let's hope the international community supports them in their efforts to diversify and shape the future of the region.

It's only natural that countries will gravitate to processes that work for them. If they find using renewable energy sources saves them money, that's what they will use.  Running a nation, is a lot like running a company. The leaders want to show something for their efforts.

It's a good sign that the Middle East seems to be finally looking seriously at renewable energy. Too often they have seem to be stuck with using oil and other polluting fuels. When I look at the issue I think about my neighbor Paul, he says he knows a lot bout energy technologies. He says that the Middle East should focus entirely on solar power. He does seem to know what he is talking about, so who am I to argue? I can see some people arguing that he doesn't have a degree or is even an expert, but that seems snobbish to me. He uses a lot of words that sound like they could be about energy and he said he watched a tv show about it once. I think that is pretty impressive and his opinion should be respected.

The UAE intends to get half its energy from renewable sources by 2050? That bodes quite well for the region, as all the other Arab countries will follow suit, of course. Since these countries tend to all be run in roughly the same way, the success of the UAE will parlay easily into similar or even better outcomes among its neighboring countries, which is going to be great for the planet!

This is pretty surprising. I would have thought those countries would be the last ones to invest in reneweables! When your whole economies are based off fossil fuels, you would think they would be opposed to solar or electric!

The more people there are the more energy will be needed. Fossil fuels will eventually run out and its only natural that people will lean toward other resources. Nature shows us that those who don't adapt end up suffering. Nature can guide us into the future with wind and solar energy.
This is getting out of control. What's next after solar?  Renewable sand for nearly unlimited energy.

Well, they know that fossil fuels are finite. It makes perfect sense for them to use the wealth they've gotten and are going to get in the coming decades from oil and invest them in things that will last beyond the death of fossil fuels. Just very smart, prudent moves on their part.

It's great that they're making this transition, although they are doing it rather slowly.   At the same time I have to think that maybe they could do something about their human rights abuses instead.  Or maybe their problems with religious extremists.   I mean,   improving energy technology isn't really going to help in those areas.   There are more important things to worry about than energy infrastructure.

It's fantastic to read that the middle east is becoming interested in implementing renewable energy sources to replace fossil fuels. Solar and wind technologies especially seem well suited to the region, I could see them doing very well with those two. I know there will be people who will resist this transition and I think their attempts will be misguided. I think back to the better days, when people would see advancements as a blessing. It seems like now everyone reacts with fury, about what will be lost and ruined with whatever new tech is revealed. What would have happened if those people were around back in our past? Would they have scoffed at the wheel? Being able to harness fire or electricity? Luckily this did not happen and people saw these inventions as blessings, this is a great thing and we must recapture this spirit. I know if we do, then we will be better for it and so will the next generation. What could be better than that?

This is good news and I'm hopeful for the future, in the region and everywhere else. Imagine how much worse it could get if we just keep focusing on fossil fuels, like some advocate for. If we stick to such an archaic energy source, all it will lead to is climate change getting worse and worse until eventually, humanity and likely all other life on earth very simply goes extinct. This isn't just about economics, but life and death.

Moral standards must be clearly defined in society to increase harmony among transcendental groups of a country. Ethical standards are formulated in intrinsic valuations contrasted against moral beliefs that are transcendent. Everyday people are that of a transcendent type and base their everyday modalities on such belief systems. Belief systems are formulated through out centuries simply know as the culture of a people. Deep rooted traditional values are signs and guidelines that maintain a natural order of harmony for the over all totality as universal knowledge and style. This is the vitalism that maintains a viability mode of existence for the populace of a territory. However if such transcendental values are held to tightly a stagnation will occur and the populace will begin to experience strife and violence. Open set of moral values must be accommodated for change to allow for what one might define as metabolism or a respiratory system that allows the culture to digest or breath new life in succession.  Impulse and extreme reflexivity with an excluded middle, meaning, catering to a virtual instead of an actuality of life is a doom loop in the making. The golden ratio must be found.

While it is very wholesome of the White Rose movement to be pushing for solidarity between Muslims and Buddhists, I think we need to make sure we are getting to the root of the actual issue here. Peace is great but what good does it do while our planet is dying? Climate change is real, and so I think we should be checking into our leaders to see if they are looking out for what's best for all, and not just for themselves.
The fact that heâs a Buddhist monk means that heâs reliable. I would agree with his campaign based on the fact that heâs a monk who demonstrates peace and love.

I don't think these protesters understand what's going on here. Either those so-called extremists get the Muslims out of their country, or it will just become a den of terrorists. Surely that's not what they want. It's not as if there are any real alternatives. This isn't a situation with a middle ground.
Islam similar to other religions is political as well as spiritual. We have to acknowledge this in order to be able to live together in an sort of harmony.

The Buddhists are just following what they know based off various world leaders when it comes to what happens to a country when Muslims come in. They know they are prone to extremism and don't want their country to deal with that.  Intellectuals like Sam Harris and Presidents like Bush and Trump have all told us how extremist Muslims can be, so these Buddhists are just doing what they can do make sure Myanmar doesn't experience that.

The root of the actual issue cannot be climate change. That is another subject that should be discussed but it has nothing to due with the White Rose campaign or the need for it in Myanmar. The root cause is more than likely due to ignorance and religious intolerance by Buddhist extremist in the country.

Do you really thick that the 100's of millions of Muslims in the world are all violent terrorists?  The actions of a few do not represent the values of the vast majority.  Your perspective is incredibly ignorant.  You are clearly stereotyping an entire religion based on the actions of extremists.  Terrorism is rarely simply the result of one thing such as religion.  Even those who commit terrorist acts in the name of religion are misguided individuals, and in some cases, religion is used as a tool to groom or coerce these individuals to commit terrible acts.  In fact, the same binary, black-or-white thinking that is used to coerce people into castigating an entire religion is the exact same black-or-white logic that you are using.

All religions need to be more supportive of each other.   The White Rose campaign is the perfect example of this.  The likelihood of one group converting is very small.  Supporting each other is the only way people will find piece.  Unity and finding ways to harmonize will lead to peace.

What a powerful gesture, and what a great idea. I wish resistance to violence with flowers and good wishes were always this effective! Let's hope this campaign is replicated in other tense regions around the world.

Actually, I wouldn't be surprised if global climate change was really the root cause. Yes, there's always been religious conflicts, but it is much more common for groups to fight over shrinking resources, which can be a result of global climate change. A well-run country with citizens who have easy access to basic necessities isn't likely to have internal religious conflicts, but if global climate change makes it more difficult to find water, food and other needs, conflicts lurking under the surface will emerge. Yes, let's quell the current unrest, but let's also focus on the bigger issue of climate change or these other problems will recur.

If there are 100 extremists so comfortable with the kind of bad behavior described here, that probably points to a much deeper rooted problem. There are probably plenty of people who support their actions. After all, extremists never simply represent themselves. They require support from a lot of layers beneath them to be able to take actions like this. Regardless, it's heartening that things like the White Rose campaign spring up to confront these kind of problems.

The media over all is owned by governments who are able to push their own agendas as something that is fact instead of being unbiased. The media is no less corrupt then the ruling government parties and the elites. It is certainly no coincidence that the media stories generally align with the popular government opinions.  Between the government and the big corporation's it's a wonder if we hear anything on the news that is truly truthful.

I'm sure this is a great work of research and due diligence, however it can't be terribly accurate because it's a compilation of expert contributions. Had the book's conclusions been based on the widespread opinions and views of the people of Myanmar (by using surveys, for example), then I would be more confident in its attempt to reflect the reality of Myanmar's media landscape and its development. Reaching out to the public and getting a sense of the majority view would give the book much more credence.

Books like these are supremely important, even when they're about other countries. The lessons they teach us are applicable everywhere, even in America. Especially in America maybe even, given the insanity of our media. We should always take every opportunity to learn, without exception. If not, we're doomed to repeat history. It's our responsibility and our only choice to keep society healthy.

It seems certain they will regress back into their former state once again, given that a smattering of the old regime and its attitudes still lingers among those in the new government. Those elements must be completely snuffed out or they will gain more and more ground until they squeeze out of government all the new reformed-minded people, and then you have a return to military rule and a clampdown on free expression.

If they want a true democratic transition, then the media has to be free. That is one of the main traditions of a democratic country and this one doesn't seem like its ready for it. Without a free media and press, a true democracy is not possible. Every democracy has and needs one.

This topic is very interesting and I hope to read more about it. It's great to hear that the country has made some positive strides, however small, even in the face of recent bad developments. A healthy media is clearly very important for the wellbeing of society, as all evidence shows. It's like Cronkite said, freedom of the press isn't just important to democracy. It is democracy.

While this is an important topic and it deserves some play there are much bigger things going on. We need to make sure that democracy is at the front of the citizens minds. That way freedom of speech and press will prevail. We can't let little things take over our minds, we need the big topics to stay out front.

It's fascinating to read that Myanmar is trending towards a media climate that is more free and open. That gives me optimism that all repressive countries are on the fast track to giving the media vast amounts of freedom. Yes is only one country, but it does show that this is possible and on the rise. Who would not find that exciting and a push towards a greater future? I can see this becoming a popular trend and all of us becoming accustomed to freedom reigning supreme. What an amazing time that will be!
Most people believe in freedom of expression. That means that it must be always the right thing in life.

Just because most people believe something,  that doesn't mean it's true.  If most people jumped off a cliff,  that wouldn't make it a good idea.     Freedom of expression is important,  but not because the majority believes in it.   In fact,  most of the world doesn't believe in free expression.  Most of the world is pretty repressive.  The book itself soom light an insightful read and Myanmar's struggle for free press and expression.   I look forward to reading it.

Freedom of expression is very important even in developing countries. Credible journalism is also essential in paving the way for reform. This book clearly shows the struggle for free speech in Myanmar, from the military junta era to now. It raises a worrying trend too, the use of old laws to suppress free speech even under civilian leadership. it's useful to bear in mind, even countries under democratic transition like Myanmar, struggle with freedom of expression.

After years of living under a repressive junta, of course people are reluctant to speak out. Because people are reluctant to speak out against inadequacies they perceive in government, the government can reasonably take the silence as acceptance of their policies and feels free to behave however it wants. Any regime leans toward obtaining more power, and without institutional checks and pushback from the citizens, the regression to full military dictatorship is inevitable.

This is crazy to read.  Countries need to adopt democracy and let the majority will of the people rule, period. It may be naive to think so, but I believe that the majority typically chooses the best way forward. People have the ability to sift through the polictical noise and make the right decisions.

The federal government needs to resolve this fast before other regions mimic this kind of behavior. Failing to get this guy replaced successfully is basically the end of the government. When lower level leaders can just defy their superiors, that's the only outcome that can occur. The government has to get this done by any means. They have no alternative.

It's only natural that those with a taste of power would not readily relinquish them. In the same vein as those who vie for power to contend with others. It's just like watching lions in the wild, the struggle for supremacy and control is always at play. There's a certain instinctual push that drives this behavior, whether in humans or animals. If you think about it, it's just akin to how a pack of wolves snarls and fights until one emerges as the alpha, it's a survival instinct ingrained in our very being. It all boils down to this same instinctual drive, the fight for survival, the acquisition of power or dominance, whether it's in politics or in the wild.

If you lose an election and refuse to step aside you should not be able to do there. There must be legal avenues to argue the validity of a election. If the losing party does not need to step down then every elected official could choose to do that and there would be chaos.

This kind of infighting is only natural among political predators. Notions like compromise, negotiation, humility, public service: they don't even occur to such figures because it is not in their nature to engage in such behaviors, any more than it's in the nature of an elephant to climb trees. Let's hope things turn out the way Afghans want it to. They have been through a lot!

I don't really understand why this is even at this point. I mean, why are governors being appointed? What ever happened to elections? The country's president shouldn't decide who the governor of a certain province is. That should be up to the majority of the people living there.

If you have an election and the losing party does not leave office how can you trust them? Most politicians are crooked and should not be trusted. People need to make sure to stay on top of these people because they all do what is in their best interest and not your best interest. People need to stay alert and informed.

This kind of infighting is innate among politicians. In fact, this trait is so native, such a natural building block of the politician's makeup, that it is the very reason he entered politics in the first place. Their love of power is like the spots on a leopard: an unchangeable mark of a particular kind of animal. We can hope for better from our leaders, but I wouldn't count on it. Besides, the fact that this trait and its results (infighting) are so naturally intrinsic to politics means they are probably the best way to approach political issues. Darwin would be proud.

What does the government expect, when they're putting in an appointment that so many of the local people are against? It's natural for people to want to choose their own leadership that actually represents their interests. The government should understand that and act appropriately instead of trying to quash their concerns.

Most countries don't have infighting quite so extreme.   This speaks to a lack of a tradition of peaceful transition of power.   Such traditions are necessary for a healthy political system.   It's unfair to these people,  they want stability and peaceful progress,   The negative precedent this sets is terrible.  Sometimes should be done about it before the problem spreads to other regions.

This is a troubling story, I can't even imagine a Governor just refusing to go and ordering the arrest of his replacement. It is such a fantastic story it is almost hard to believe that this has actually occurred. Even with how crazy of an event it is, I am thinking that Afghanistan have much bigger fishes to fry than this stubborn Governor. The Taliban for one is obviously a major ongoing problem that should be taken on immediately. The economy, poverty and the treatment of women all need to come before this issue as well. I understand that this story will make a splash and attract a lot of interest, but Afghanistan needs to stay focused on these major issues. Politics are always messy and we can't find ourselves caught in the circus when so much needs to be done already. I sincerely hope that the Afghan leadership will lead here and do the right thing for the whole country.
