This doesn't seem very natural. I mean, how many other countries are there where you can say such a situation is happening? Definitely never heard of any kind of crazy situation like this in the US. But we can agree, hope Afghans get to move past all this craziness and get what they want.

This has been going on for as long as I've been alive. I'm not sure what is needed to stop it, especially in big cities. I feel for their families. Will the BLM movement help with this? I doubt it, but who knows?

So true! Police brutality has really taken a huge jump in recent years. I just wonder would is going to happen in the future if the police keep on the track they are on now? Will it get worse? I can't imagine it being better. Aggressive policing continues to go unchecked and if it keeps happening, we might see a huge increase in conflicts, not only with minorities but with other groups too. It is so scary to think that if we don't do something now, we can be witnessing the deterioration of societal peace. Police should be respect, but they make it hard to do that when they continue to use brutality toward people, especially minorities. Right?

The police usually do a good job in New York, I believe.  Just because one man was unjustly killed doesn't mean the whole system is out for blacks.  Nor does it mean Cuomo willingly protected a lot of racist actions.  Why must people always jump to negative conclusions? People who love criticizing the system always base their opinions on an isolated incident.  Let's look at a broader set of data first.

This has been going on for decades now. I feel like there are 2 options here: Take guns away from cops like the UK does or just deal with the fact that this is going to happen occasionally. Maybe you could also spend millions on completely new training methods for cops?

Why does everyone think that a protest and movement will do anything? This has been going on for years and nothing has changed. Protesting isn't going to change it either. Think of all the protests we have seen on the past, most of them yielded no concrete changes. We should really think about how we can directly influence policy changes. Maybe the people protesting for change should be the first to sign up to be officers to begin the change? They could bring the perspective and actually effect the change they want to see from within. It would do a lot more to help than just standing outside with a sign, don't you think?

The killing of Amadou Diallo was tragic it is not isolated. We need to look at police brutality and profiling on a larger scale. These men George Floyd and Amadou Diallo did not deserve what they received from police. But neither do the hundreds of thousands of black Americans who to deal with police brutality on a daily basis. This was all horrible. None of this should have happened.

The fact that these cops were acquitted means that more cops are going to think they can get away with murder and end up killing innocents just because they think they can! If you don't punish people, obviously others will feel emboldened! Soon the cops will be the criminals! Who will stop them at that point?

Every single instance of policy brutality needs to be fully accounted for. If not, it can only get worse. Cops are already murdering people with virtual impunity, so long as they can passably pretend they were afraid. What's next? They won't even have to use that excuse? They will just become judge, jury, and executioner? How much more power will these killers eventually get if they're not stopped?

The notion of "guns or no guns" envelops the discourse, we often overlook the nuanced options that could front a real change. We should try to address the safety concerns at its root for change. Mandatory police courses could instill a better understanding of handling weapons and ensuring safety in situations. Our schools could be nurturing ground for budding minds on safety norms. Are we missing out on a golden opportunity to reform our system? It's time we accept that multiple, smaller changes strung together could bring a bigger, sustainable change.

It's true that we need to address every instance of police brutality, there is no justification for excess violence by anyone. Having said that, I don't think we will ever reach the point of the police being given total freedom to execute whomever they wish. There is no reason to go to that extent in your argument, what police officers have done to this point is already bad enough. We must also make clear that many police officers do not cross the line, we must give credit when they show restraint especially when it may be difficult. If we are always pointing out the negatives and ignoring all positives then it dampens the efforts to actually improve the interactions. We should strive for that, not just because it's right, but also for the memory of Amadou Diallo. He didn't deserve the treatment he received and it would further dishonor him if we let the system continue to be broken. #JusticeForAmadou

This might look like a slippery slope argument, but I agree with it and I think it's more like a warning. The threat of legal punishment for police officers who overstep their bounds will certainly make them thinking deeper about their actions, whereas the likelihood of escaping punishment will just embolden them. If there had been a pattern of justice for victims of police brutality, could further incidents have been prevented?

I think most cops are honest and try to help people.  Sure, there are some bad apples in the bunch, but we can't say there all bad because of the actions of a few.  However, the violence against black Americans should be stopped.  I hope the court systems and judges, with their given authority, will prosecute some of the cops who harm blacks without reason. Such scrutiny is needed.  As Professor Benjamin Marshall said, "A just society stems from an impartial judiciary that hold everyone to account, irrespective of their profession."
Using machine learning to push a language is odd. What other agenda will they push with their tech? I don't know if this is a good precedence.

It's great that these people are finding ways to preserve their languages and cultures. It's entirely natural to want to honor your heritage and pass it down. Of course, it's also natural and great to assimilate into larger cultures, but there can be a healthy balance.

No doubt, people are naturally inclined to lean towards languages they are already fluent in. However, bringing the Shona language to an online platform is a worthy move. Even if it may feel alien to some, it's important to remember that the crux of any language is communication, something that is deeply ingrained in our DNA as human beings. Even as we honor the intrinsic direction of linguistic choices, one should not undermine the earnest attempts made to protect cultural jewels like the Shona language. The Internet, a key instrument in our lives, is gradually shaping our communication practices.

I think it is important that traditional languages be preserved. Making sure they are online will be vital in that process. This makes information accessible to many. It keeps these traditions alive and preserved for future generations.

Languages evolved alongside communities, and it's just as natural that people want to preserve them. I applaud the efforts made here to make sure these native languages don't die out. Each language carries a slice of that natural evolution of our species and each should be preserved.

Preserving one's own language through time and change is indeed the right thing to do, and it's encouraging to see such dedication. Traditionally, respecting and upholding an ancestral language has always been thought of as a testament to our identity and heritage - a sentiment that's been held true for generations. Isn't it reassuring to believe in the unchanging truth of our traditions, regardless of whether or not it has universal applicability? This should inspire us all to keep the flame of our linguistic heritage alive for future generations to appreciate and engage with. After all, isn't tradition what makes us who we are?
People will try to preserve their tradition. So shona as a natural online language may or may not work. It certainly won't go global, but might suffice for local use.

This seems like a waste of time for a talented engineer working with AI. The people who speak this language probably speak a more common language as well, so they don't need to rely on their native one. Spend your time using AI to help cure real problems like diseases or something! Its a nice idea, but at the end of the day, a language used by only 10 million people, many of whom probably don't even use computers, isn't that big of a deal.

It's great that these people are making efforts to preserve their language. If such things aren't done, the languages just die out, as many have already. And where does that end? It extends to everything from music to literature to recipes to basic traditions. Before you know it, the culture is just a thing for the history books.

Things that are beyond a lost language can still prosper. The language may die from lack of need, but other parts of the culture will live on if they are wanted. Keeping records of the culture can be done while still letting the culture change and fade. Technology can help with this as well and can make it hard to lose the past thankfully.

It's so encouraging to see this kind of combination: intelligence and technical prowess plus pride (the right kind of pride - i.e., in one's history and tradition). This is exactly the kind of person who gets projects like this done, and he's an articulate spokesperson for its widespread support. Keep up the great work!

Many people value their culture and their languages. For them, the lack of their language in online spaces is a real problem. Not everyone on the planet has to focus all their efforts on curing diseases or something. There's nothing wrong with people like Blessing Sibanda focusing on this problem.

Military governments are cannot work for any civilized country. Myanmar should pursue democracy like we have in order to appeal to human nature. This will help things to work better as it causes humans to thrive.

This is very concerning. I hope the activists can make some headway, and perhaps the international community can pressure the military leadership in Myanmar to repeal the bill and give more thought to the importance of basic human freedoms. If we are united in our opposition to this kind of crackdown, perhaps we can effect change not only in Myanmar but around the world.
The military government in Myanmar seems to be pretty severe. The people might be concerned about potential coup. First Vice President Myint Swe, do you agree with this? Is this democratic?

We have to understand though that people in Myanmar might not want the same cyber freedoms as we do. Perhaps most people are okay with this . I have a friend who lives there and said he is not concerned with internet restrictions. It is possible that with their unique culture, most of Myanmars  population might not view cyber restrictions in a negative manner.
Once they start to to such things, it won't stop. It will get worse from here. Could lead to a crisis.

They have a coup going on right now. Maybe they should be organizing to take control over their government first and focus on the internet after! What's more important, the internet or the military trampling over everyone?
A government that wants to censor should always be questioned. It is troubling that a tool for citizens to communicate would be controlled so heavily.

They are doing this because they plan to commit genocide against their people. There is no other explanation for why they would want this bill enacted! Any country that wants to censor info and shut down dissent has genocide on their agenda!

Do you think your single friend is representative of the whole population? I have a friend in America who might say the same thing, but that certainly doesn't mean Americans are pro-censorship. I mean, I get the underlying point that we should always consider what people actually want and should recognize that others don't always share our values. But I don't think it's fair to sow doubt based on what one friend of yours says or thinks.

This is unsurprising. Any group wishing to seize control over a vast population, as this one has by means of a coup, must exert a death grip on the flow of information. It's tragic but unsurprising. It's encouraging to see local organizations standing up against the potential cyber law.

There are a host of human rights violations being committed systematically, but throttling the internet is a catastrophic blow to transparency, information access, and other very basic needs. This isn't just about sharing cat videos. This is about keeping a population under control, like North Korea. Addressing the internet ban doesn't diminish other human rights issues, which are very important; in fact, a free internet could expose those issues to a wide audience. Government-imposed internet blackouts need to be called out wherever they crop up.

While this probably isn't a good step for the country, isn't that a bit much? I mean, there's no other imaginable reason to censor online content except to commit genocide? If that were the case, we'd have a few more hundred genocides going on in all the countries that in some way censor info.
Most world citizens will be so relieved at this progress so this is a welcomed step to the future. This is great news in the struggle for lgbtq rights.

The Tunisian government should either make LGBT stuff legal or make it all illegal. This would do away with any similar lawsuits being brought up. You can't make being gay illegal and then allow an LGBT radio station. Mixed signals. Either legalize it all or not!

Having religious and free speech is natural need of people all over the world. We need to stop government censorship. Government censorship is never a good thing, it leads to discontent in many other areas as well.

I agree, they need to get rid of censorship, I agree with getting rid of censorship. Removing censorship will let people live the way they want and to voice their opinions on what they believe. Let people live the way that they want to and not let them face problems if they choose to do so.

Although I approve of the actions of the Tunisian government when it comes to their recent rulings, it seems a bit hypocritical in my opinion. I can see it is confusing to some of its citizens as well. If you as a country ban same sex relationships, how are you allowing a radio station to cater to these same individuals? They need to be clear and consistent on where they stand on this issue.

Do you think all people agree with that? There are lots who prefer security over things like free speech. Whether they expand or restrict free speech for their people should be a matter that the majority of people in those countries decide, not what some people think is a natural need.

It's good that the high court ruled against censorship. But that doesn't mean that all types of material should be allowed. I think it's easy to say if there is material out there promoting death to certain groups of people, that should be illegal.

I see where you're coming from, but I don't think it's necessarily hypocritical. For example, in America, we're allowed to say and discuss plenty of things that wouldn't be legal to actually do. As the most extreme example, we can make movies depicting murder. More reasonably and more related to what might be happening here - even when say same sex marriage was illegal, it wasn't as if it was illegal to go on the radio or wherever and talk about how it should be legal. I suspect the same was true back in the days homosexuality itself was illegal in America. Speech and action are two different things.
Most people believe the radio station should be banned. So the will of the people should be enforced. The majority has a say, and the courts should not take that away.

This makes me think that muslim countries are finally coming around when it comes to gay rights. I bet the next thing is gay marriage being legalized! Any other Muslim country would have banned the radio station, but this one did not. I think that proves they're progressing.
The government ruled that it was alright to keep the radio station going. Might makes right, so the decision is absolutely right!

I assume the court had a legal reason for its decision, but it wasn't wrong for the imams to bring forth a suit. Someone needs to uphold traditional values. I understand times inevitably change, and I do value free speech, but it's also true that traditional values have sustained Arab countries for centuries. I think the effort to preserve them is ultimately a noble one.
It is at the point where the internet is a human need. Others need to be connected for information and education, as well as economic reasons.
Everyone in Gambia should just listen to the leaders. Things will go smoother for everyone. Some may argue, but trust is important.

It's encouraging to hear that people like Momodou Gajaga are able to maintain their digital/internet connections. That means there is hope for connectivity across all of Gambia, which is very reassuring. If Gajaga can maintain his connection, I'm sure many or even most in Gambia can do so too. But let's keep working to make things better!

It is only natural for people to want access to information. People need access to the internet as it has now become an essential part of life. It is a connection to the economy, knowledge,  way to connect with people all around the world. We need a plan to ensure all people have equal access to the internet.

What can be done here? The government needs to drastically step up their internet infrastructure or they need to force the ISPs to lower prices so their people can have access. What else is there? I think the best option is for them to invest as much as possible in their infrastructure.

I agree with you that it is important to listen to the leaders, but what happens when the majority of them don't have  your best interest in mind? Should people listen to them then? I am sure the majority of the leaders aren't looking out for the  people's best interest. I am sure a majority of us have been let down by actions that seem to favor the powerful few over the general population. I am pretty sure that most people would feel the same way I do.
Internet should be accessible to all. Governments should make it a basic amenity. Otherwise, things just get bad. The pandemic showed just how crucial internet access is.

I hope that digital reform can be put in place for the people soon. Unreliable internet access can lead to further losses in productivity and expression, setting the nation further behind. A nation lagging behind in the digital race can turn towards more questionable methods to accelerate development. This can lead to greater data breaches, restrictions, and widespread distrust in the government. Action must be taken quickly.

The country really needs to prioritize internet access. Nearly the whole world considers it a basic necessity these days, and for good reason. Surely most of the people in the country also understand this and demand functioning infrastructure for the net. Give the people what they want!
The government should alter facts and make this look favorable. They need to report the truth, or society will live a lie. Factual reporting should be above political gain.

It would be nice for Gambia to step up their internet service for their entire population, just reading the stories from the affected residents is troubling. I must disagree with your fatalist vision though, not having the best internet does not guarantee the end of Gambia. It is not a great thing obviously, but instead of stoking fears we should be proposing ideas to improve the situation. The government can improve it's internet exchange point which will add additional connection speed to its citizens, also it can open the market to allow more competition. More competition almost always ensures lower costs and lower costs means more people in Gambia can afford internet. These and many other solutions are the key here to boost the access to the internet for all. I am excited to see what the future will be with Gambia rightfully involved!

The cost of internet access there is startlingly high. It's almost unbelievable. It's not just an economic issue but is really about fundamental human rights like having access to information and the ability to participate in the digital world (not to mention being able to make a living). That needs to change and we need pressure from international groups to bring about that change. Let's go.

The political situation in Myanmar is becoming strange. How have the politicians become so removed from the needs of the people. And why do they allow such human rights violations to continue? Please give the people back the internet. Please let them tell us what's happening so we can offer assistance.

Its awful that not much has been done by the United Nations Office to address this crisis. I hope that internet service and the humanitarian response needs to be improved upon in order for the crisis to be under control and this crisis gets resolved.
Losing internet will not hurt society. The region survived without internet for centuries and can move on without it. Humans need to enjoy the world more anyway.

Why is the focus on the internet shutdowns, and not that actual human rights abuses from the insecurity caused by the coup. There has been enough evidence based on the statistics to show that Myanmar needs more international intervention. It is important to get news out from the people in Myanmar, but we need to focus on the problem itself which is the insecurity caused by the coup.

I agree that we can live and go on without internet, the world doesn't have to stop because of it. Of course it will be a different lifestyle than what your used to, but it'll work out, so you might miss being on the cell phone all of the time, but the world is heating up.

I think that dismissive attitudes about this conflict-riddled region of Sagaing is so out of touch. Was the internet shut down in Myanmar to stop the spread of false news? Has the internet been commandeered by people who are regular internet users or who are not regular Internet users but conflicting factions within the Sagaing Region? Itâs not really a case of one or the other, is it? Im sure many people there use the Internet for numerous reasons. Either way, how can the people âenjoyâ anything during such horrendous human atrocities and displacements.

Almost everybody has been affected by the shutdowns. And everyone says it is terrible. Having a junta shutting down the internet does not bode well for the citizens, so the people need to revolt, like most countries do

If there is no internet people will not be able to learn or work. It will be like they are back in the dark ages. We have to choose, do we want to be in the stone age or the digital age? The internet is a crucial part of our global society. Bring back the internet for Myanmar!

Thank you for pointing out the obvious issue with this article! Why on earth are we focusing on the internet shutdown and not all the humans rights issues that they're attempting to cover up! We will never make any progress on this humanitarian crisis if we pour all of our resources into a symptom, not the cause. I think the world community needs to reassess their priorities!

I agree that the actual abuses going on in Myanmar are frightening and need to be addressed, however that doesn't mean we shouldn't talk about them shutting off the internet to their citizens. In fact having internet access will only help raise awareness and let us understand what actual abuses are going on. If we allow the silence of the victims of this coup then we will never know the truth of what is actually happening, that is simply not acceptable. I feel that we can and must face both of these problems at the same time, anything else is just dangerous.  I certainly hope that the United Nations will step up here, way too little going on in terms of actual results.

Not allowing people to communicate with each other is just as evil and unnatural. Humans are social beings and we all need to communicate with one another, especially in trying times like what the people of Myanmar are going through. They need their internet access back! They are already being displaced and killed, but taking away their right to talk to their loved ones as well?

This is simply one article. In fact, the article explains that the internet blackout makes it harder for people there to show evidence of these atrocities taking place. I agree that there needs to be more outside help from international agencies however they can make that happen. However, if there is no way for people to communicate what is happening, it is going to be mighty difficult for anyone to help them. Certain infrastructure must be in place in a modern society to effectively deal with things like this. So much hinges on internet and networks like this to operate. It is important to understand that these people need to have the access to the internet in order to begin to address the humanitarian crisis there. I hope international agencies see an article like this and it spurs them to action to help these people that are being oppressed. I hope something happens that helps these people out, I feel for them.

The memories of people continue to preserve the reality of events, as it is in their nature to hold on to the truth. As they say, you can't fool all the people all the time. Ever noticed how even the most forgotten parts of history find their way back to our consciousness? That's nature for you. The attempt to rewrite history is not only going against the natural order but also invites the natural repercussions, as nature works in its own mysterious ways to restore balance. Accepting what has happened may seem difficult but it is the most natural way to heal and move forward. One can't just turn the existing natural laws upside-down without expecting some form of reckoning. Let's let the nature take its course. After all, the true story of our past is the foundation on which we build our future.

Some believe that the democratization of China is a good thing, but only think this way because it has become a popular opinion. It's hardly a simple matter. Perhaps the Chinese government knows what it best after all. Many do think that the current Chinese government have their priorities straight. We should let people decide for themselves.

The problem with communists government is they always try to tell their own story.  The only way they have been able to stay in power is through fear.  Fear that any challenge to their power will result in more death.  The souls of 202 people being lost is sad, but so is the loss of freedom.   This tradition should remain alive, as should the tradition of questioning the truth of what happened on June 4.

The fact that you said democracy is only a good think since its popular leads me to believe you are a CCP shill or work for the CCP. I have never seen anyone else who doesn't work for a one-part state say this before.

It is quite troubling to say the least that the Chinese government continues to deny the real extent of the events that unfolded at the Tiananmen Massacre. Many people died that day and to not even acknowledge the facts about the event is just absurd by the Chinese government and to censure the information regarding it is even worse. This event did take place whether the Chinese government acknowledges it or not.

You know how China is with dissent, so if I were in Hong Kong, I would quit it with this or they will be killed by the Chinese. They kill their own people, so they will kill you to seeing as they already sort of consider HK theirs. Especially when you are trying to bring attention to something that they have been trying to bury for decades!
It is definitely the issue with communist governments. They can push the narrative that they want. And it works for a lot of the citizens because they aren't allowed to seek outside sources.

For you to use democracy and the Chinese government in the same sentence must mean you are either clueless as to what democracy is or you are a troll who is representing the CCP. We all know what the government is all about. They might allow you to vote which is a democratic act, but you are still selecting officials with communist beliefs.

It seems that their narrative is working for outside observers as well. You stated 202 lost but it is very likely the number was in the thousands. It is important that the push for truth and transparency continues.

What a horrific event back in 1989. I remember the images of the tanks versus the students. Let's hope there is a brighter future ahead for the people of Hong Kong, and for the citizens of mainland China too.

It's great that the people here aren't forgetting their true past. Commemorations have always been an important part of humanity. And that tradition is for good reason as well. This vigil and other events like it are the only way the crimes of the CCP will not be forgotten, and an important part of how they'll be stopped in the future.
It seems very honorable what he is doing. He is standing up for his beliefs even at the cost of visiting his family. That is the only brave thing to do.
Things in China only get worse. The government will never admit wrongdoing. Doing that undermines their stance on being faultless as a system of governance.

This person is not only advocating for a violent revolution, but for foreign nations to wage war to remove the government that they don't like? Frankly, as bad as the government of China is in many ways, they're still in ways a lot more palatable to me than people who say things like this. If you're faced with the nearly billion plus 'brainwashed' and 'ignorant' population and can't manage to convince anyone but a tiny minority to support your ideas, the response shouldn't be inciting violence.
Most people know the massacre was a travesty. Any government to do that should be removed. Time will judge the perpetrators of tragic killings.

Yes, its not smart what he's doing. If enough people hear his rhetoric in China, it could lead to them actually trying something which would obviously lead to tons of death. Once China finds out they tried something due to his rhetoric, the CCP could kill everyone he knows.

I think you're totally right. He's putting himself in real danger and sacrificing a lot, but we have honored heroes like this for all of history for good reason. He represents the ideals of freedom and truth that we have always valued. I wish him the best of luck in his mission.
It's natural to feel a need for justice when wronged. The survivors will continue to seek what's right. The CCP on the other hand will continue to suppress any opposition to their agenda.

Most residents of the area don't feel so harshly on what happened. Perhaps their views should be listened to as well. Everyone should recognize there are differing views out their and should be given a fair hearing.

At this point, why bother? China is stronger than ever and the people in charge have complete control over the people. They won this battle. They think having everyone forget or not even find out about 1989 is best, so that's what is gonna happen. Is there anyone who really thinks that after 30 years, the authorities in China will lose or change their minds/

It may be natural to want justice when you are wronged, but does that make it right? Does it even matter if it feels natural or not? I would imagine a lot of horrible things seem natural to a mentally unwell person. Does that make them okay? I feel that the survivors of the Tiananmen Massacre deserve to have justice,   not because it is natural but because the pain they have suffered. Do you see the difference there? We agree mostly on this, but I think we should leave behind the naturalness of things.

its a terrible situation and i think even more terrible is the fact that the country that did this does not bear any responsibility or blame when it comes to it. its just sad and a terrible situation. i feel bad for the people

Well, if everyone took your attitude, they definitely won't. What do you suggest, that the people of China simply give up and live under authoritarians for the rest of time? It's important that people like this keep up their efforts and that nobody throws in the towel.

At least they have some freedom of press. What about countries where media has no freedom at all?  This is important for media freedom however, this is just not a problem in one country. We should make this a goal for freedom of press in as many countries instead of focusing on just one.
This is a direct impact of the law and a direct result of the government policy. To blame an economic impact only is poor judgment.
Hong Kong is finished. The people need to rise up and take control. If China keeps weighing their influence on HK, things will get worse.

It is only natural that people seek information. Something needs to be done to make sure they still have the right to it through freedom of press. Information is like water necessary to life but something everyone deserves.

You believe Hong Kong is finished just because of a single law and a few examples of it maybe negatively affecting the country?  I think you are jumping to a conclusion without weighing all the facts and understanding that laws can be complex and their outcomes evolve over time. I understand the initial concern but we have to look at these issues with a discerning eye to see what the actual effects and their causes are.  At this point we are not sure if the concerns to this law will not be addressed and improve the law in the long run. I really hope that in the end all these concerns will actually lead to a more free Hong Kong and the people who live there.

This is troubling and tragic. Everyone knows that the financial boom of Hong Kong is due to the lack of constraint (economic freedom!). But what has worked so well for markets is not being allowed to benefit the actual people who live and work there. More freedom, always more freedom, is the way to solve problems, not repression and crackdowns! Stay strong, Hong Kong: your struggle reminds us all of the value of freedom.
Those who know say media freedom is bad in HK now. They need to rise up. China will keep influencing HK negatively, to make it more like China .

Outlets in HK either have to stand and fight by continuing to post their pro-democracy articles, or shut down. One is the moral thing to do, the other is the cowards way out! You could also just cow two to China and switch to posting pro-china content, but that's even worse.

Hong Kong and China in general have had centuries of authoritarianism. A few decades of a more liberal system under the rule of the British can't really change that. Authoritarianism, at least in their culture, has withstood the test of time a lot better than the alternative that was offered.

Making an overall judgement like that can be a bit defeatist. Knowing that one side is better then the other should give energy to pushing towards it. Authoritarianism has been around a long time, but it doesn't give it freedom to reign free. We need to advocate for and support the brave journalist who continue their work against these challenges.

Media freedom is so important! Atrocities like this shouldn't be happening anywhere. If these regulations are replicated in other parts of the world, there's a risk that we'll all be silenced sooner rather than later. Democracies worldwide might begin to crumble under restrictions that clamp down on freedom of speech. Let's keep standing up for media freedom, everyone!

Precisely, their intentions have been shown. Waiting to see how it turns out, as you propose, could be disastorous. They have already shown their cards in what they want to do. They want to limit the media and make sure that the message is what they want, this has to be taken seriously now. The free world must begin to advocate for a free press in Hong Kong.
Most people believe local languages are key to identity. So it is a good thing to preserve. With time, they will gain some prominence.

It's wonderful to see such recognition, so hard-earned and a long time coming. But let's be careful, too. While social progress and the recognition of all people groups is good, we must not make changes too quickly, as these patterns of social order have been in place in the region for a very long time. Reform is always welcome but not at the expense of long established views which have so powerfully shaped such a large part of the world.  Let's strive for changes that honor tradition while making room for progress.

It's great that these people are able to thrive while preserving their languages, customs, and the like. All those things are traditions that go back countless centuries, and they shouldn't be abandoned in order to fit into whatever the mainstream culture is. The old ways withstood the test of time, and they should merely remain the old ways, but be maintained as the current ways as well.
The indigenous people have had it rough. This is common in most of the world. Others take over your lands and then erode your culture and life.

I feel like just because they're indigenous doesn't mean that the majority of the nation should base economic and environmental laws around what they want. The majority of the nation is not indigenous, so their wants and needs should be given more weight. That solar plant and nuclear plant that they stopped could probably have really helped the entire economy there.

It's great that they're finally getting the recognition and respect that they deserve. It's to the benefit of the non-indigenous as well, and they in Taiwan should take note of that. As award winning author Jay Griffiths said, if people can't acknowledge the wisdom of indigenous cultures, that's their loss.
Most people will agree it's important to preserve culture. The indigenous singers are right. They need to do what they can to keep their origins alive.

These people are just trying to save and bring attention to their cultures and traditions. They are the true Taiwanese and because of that deserve to have their wants and needs met. They have been there the longest after all. They know what is best for them and the country as a whole.

Undeniably, people across different cultures and backgrounds naturally have the gumption to go forward, even amidst challenging odds. But that doesn't downplay the crucial role adaptation and resilience play. Face with ever-changing external forces, the strength to overcome surges from within, not just as 'nature intended,' but also due to intrinsic determination and enduring spirits. Therefore, overcoming adversity to these indigenous folks is more a testament of their own desire to thrive than just a matter of mere "nature's course." In the grand scheme of things, it seems only natural that humans, having sprouted from the bosom of nature, encompass the inherent ability to withstand adversity.
It's always encouraging to see these kinds of reversals. When an oppressed or forgotten people achieve greatness, you just can't ignore it. Congratulations indigenous peoples of Taiwan! Keep shining.

I don't believe anyone is suggesting that minorities should be the dictators of their countries or something. Just that their concerns and needs should be taken into account when making decisions, such as their concerns about the nuclear power plant. Without doing that, you just have a tyranny of the majority. And ultimately, the indigenous people alone didn't make that decision. As noted in the article, a referendum voted on by all Taiwanese citizens is what stopped the power plant.

When it comes to indigenous cultures, I almost feel like it's a dangerous road to try and be well known. Since the westernization of most cultures has caused a lot of erosion of ethics and morals as well. So while it's good that they receive some recognition let's hope that they can remain authentic.

These kids are not only ruining their lives, but the lives of everyone around them. They need to listen to the cops and stop rioting. It will accomplish nothing at all. Not listening to them will just mean JAIL. They don't know the ins and outs of what goes on in the government, so they shouldn't be rioting for something they have no part in.

These are very dangerous protests happening on the campuses in Hong Kong. These types of anti government protest could potentially spark a countrywide revolution if not contained. It is necessary to allow protests of the government, but this may end up getting out of control given the fact that these protests are becoming increasingly violent on both the police and protester sides.

Why aren't the students just obeying the police?  The protesting won't solve anything anyway so they may as well stop.  The police have authority and should be respected. MLK, Jr. said riots are the language of the unheard.  Riots aren't enough.  These things require systematic reforms and cooperation with authorities and government.
They should just go with the majority of the ruling entity China. Why go against something that will only lead to violence. Most of the people can't be wrong can they? Follow the crowd for peace.
The problems aren't with the police, the problems are with the government! Why aren't they focusing on the corrupt politicians? All of their problems are caused by the politicians!

There's no denying that on the surface level, it's a choice between continuing to protest or going to jail or adhering to the law and halting protests.   They could have constructive dialogues, too.  How about that?
Maybe going along with what has been done in the past in one of the largest countries in the world. Tradition has power to it and can be very rewarding. Old is gold, as they say.

Hong Kong is the last place I'd want to protest right now with how much Power China has over them nowadays. Protesting the government will risk your freedom and life. Its not like the old Hong Kong anymore. I wish they could overcome the China influence, but it looks impossible at this point.

What happens if protesters like these students are attacked and not allowed to ever protest or question anything?  They will eventually be silenced completely.  Then, the government will either endure their wrath or really end up injuring these people.  That will have horrible repercussions in their society like a dystopian nightmare.

The police in Hong Kong seem to have been rather excessive in their response, though the protesters did seem to be acting violently themselves. Taking that all into mind, I can't agree that this is a step towards ending all protests and I definitely do not think this is the path to a dystopian nightmare. We should argue about whether the police went too far, but we shouldn't claim this is surely the end of the free world. We should also make clear that the protesters have to maintain peaceful protests, they endanger the right to protest by acting in a violent manner. That is the only way we will find a proper resolution, with peaceful discussions that bridge the gaps between the two parties. I hope that happens before anymore people are hurt!

"Where is Carry Lam?" is a great question, and the administration needs to step up. The relationship between China and Hong Kong is a long and complex one, and I don't see how some riots are going to change that. But meanwhile, the leadership in Hong Kong is weak and ineffectual. It seems protesting for good local government should be a more pressing and achievable goal to those in Hong Kong than trying to gain full autonomy from China.

The students should have been allowed to peacefully protest.  They are optimistic young people who care about their future. The government needs to initiate a dialogue rather than resort to violence.  Peaceful negotiation is key.  These young people will be the future of Hong Kong one day.

We have all known for decades now that China is a bad country and its pretty much tradition at this point to not trust them, especially if you live close to them and their government. The people of Hong Kong who are supporting the blue businesses are doing a huge disservice to their people and their country. They should know what will happen if China wins and these protestors lose!

The Chinese government and its red economy only care about themselves. They think that their way to govern and oppress its citizens by taking away their basics human rights, is the only way to run a nation. It is good to see the people of Hong Kong standing up for themselves and their rights. I once heard someone who was an expert speaking on how the Chinese economy flourishes off of oppressing its people and taking away their rights. That is a scary thought as their economy is growing and becoming a true world power.

The news on this topic is interesting to me. The internet 'news' makes it seem like Hong Kong wants nothing to do with China and that these protests truly represent the popular will. I have a few friends from Hong Kong, and they all love China. Strange. Seems like the news isn't interested in reporting what the people actually think.

Things are hardcore in Hong kong. It's a good thing that the businesses are supporting the people. Without the business supporting protests they may not be able to continue. It's important for people to be heard. Without the support the people might not be able to continue. Without them the people would run out of steam. And then there may be more consequences to the economy of Hong Kong that they haven't predicted.

These people are choosing to lose things based on their opinions. What about children who have no choice about the fact that they are going hungry. I don't understand helping those who are making the choice to go hungry. I think our energy would be better spent helping the innocent victims like children.

It seems only natural that there has become a groundswell movement of people yearning for freedom in the current global climate. They see how the western world works and want in on that. It seems to me that this is just the necessary consequence of Chinas repressive government and stopping it is futile.

People in Hong Kong should understand that this is not the path to peace. How do they think China will react to things like this, by just letting it go? No, they will only clamp down more and more. More impositions, more repressive laws, probably culminating in violent, military action. Hong Kong will only hasten it becoming the next Xinjiang with these kinds of actions.
China has long been known as a communist country and it appears that is continuing, despite small businesses supporting the protests. I hope they get the support they need.

We all have seen situations like the one you speak of. Your friends do not represent the entire country or the majority of people in Hong Kong though. Perhaps they have it good so why would they not say they love the Chinese government. We cannot conclude things based on a small example of people. I am sure there are some who love the Chinese government, but they are not the only voice in that country. From everything that I have seen and read, the majority are not fans of the Chinese government.

Chow Hin is wrong, in my view. You have to come down on one side or the other. Yellow all the way, or Blue all the way. Dabbling in both can only cause confusion in the minds of those who want to do business but wish to stand against the mainland government. Decisiveness is required in situations like these, especially when others are trying to suss out whether they can trust you.

This is definitely going to help those that are trying to fight back against China and the corruption of the HK gov, but I'd be worried, if I were a business, about supporting them openly. They could probably easily shut us down, no? I would try and support them, but not openly and definitely not advertise that I was doing so!

Not great for these 'blue' shops, but they have nobody to blame but themselves. Either they support the protests and stand up for democracy, or they lose their business. They need to make a real choice as there is no middle ground. There is no way to just pretend the massive changes happening aren't a big deal.
